reviewText:
Altough a quite unfinished product as what it is, Alpha Protocol has much to offer in the form of the choices you will have to make during your career which in turn will have an effect on your future as an agent. Rather than just being the same old Mikey all the time, you can change your angle of approaching different people, by sometimes pis**** them off with the aggressive style often associated to Jack Bauer or you can just keep them doing favors for you because of the suave style of James Bond you chose to use. Maybe aggressive and suave styles will not always work and you want to keep yourself in the line of duty by being a professional like Jason Bourne. The thing is, you need to learn to adapt yourself to the ever changing environment.

When it comes to the action, you can choose to upgrade your skills to match those of Rambo's or put all your efforts on sneaking, depending on which one is more to your liking as a gaming style. Knowing your enemy by simply collecting all the available intel on him/her, gives you a huge advantage if you two decide to pick up a fight. Of course, it's not once or twice you can avoid being beaten up by a giant boxer if you choose the correct phrases. Just be sure to create good relations with the people you meet, and you will find yourself being helped by different organisations if the price is right.

Now, I beat Alpha Protocol twice on PS3 system soon after the game was released, and decided to buy it also for my laptop because of the glorious moments I had with it while playing it on PS3 years ago. To this date I have played this game through six times on my laptop, once with every background, and not until now can I say I know just about every twist this game has to offer.

Do I need to say anything more? Alpha Protocol has offered me good gaming experiences and memories in the form of a modern espionage RPG. If you are a gamer who dares to look beneath the surface of this highly underrated piece of art, I have no doubt you find yourself being comfortable with it. Just don't forget to turn up the radio guys!

reviewText:
Introduction:Alpha Protocol combines an enthralling storyline with a functioning role playing core and the highest grade of replayability in years! This game is my favorite Spy game to date of writing this review (3/29/2016). It has it's flaws but at it's core is an amazing game. Look beyond its obvious faults and Alpha Protocol isn’t frustratingly bad, but frustratingly good; that is, if you care to look that hard.

Positive:+ An astounding variety of ethical decisions that affect how the story unfolds
+ A wide range of believable, fun characters; characters that you just have to love (and hate)
+ Great FPS with a plethora of guns to choose from with attachments
+ Government thriller story that allows you to pick which route you want to go
+ Romantic options
+ Multiple endings
+ Excellent execution of FPS/RPG with fun minigames (hacking/lock-picking)
+ Character creation allows for different types of playstyles

Negatives:- Game designed for console that causes a lot of bugs for PC port (listed below)
- AI is bad, sometimes it reminds me of old school Goldeneye
- Crosshair/Accuracy, bullets just seem to randomly miss no matter where the crosshair is placed
- No Sniper Rifle as a choice of guns to upgrade, although placed in game in missions
- Bugs, overall a terrible PC port
- No Achievements
- No Steam trading cards

Fails of computer port:- Hacking is extremely tedious sometimes moving the mouse to get to the correct location
- Mouse sensitivity is terrible, hard to adjust for multiple weapons (IE: moving then using sniper rifle)
- Camera movement was bad, I ended up getting used to it though
- Graphics could be better, designed for consoles
- No hotkeys/gadgets for skills because it was designed with limited buttons of a controller
- Bugs again

Good Game: 7/10, could be a 10/10 GOTY if they fixed their computer port issues (or made a game specifically for the PC)

Good game that's a MUST BUY during a sale. I think it's even worth full price ($14.99 at the time of writing this). It is a rare game that I might actually replay. I am the type of person who can only watch a movie once, same with games. Alpha Protocol might break the trend when I replay it. This was one of those games I just couldn't stop playing.

It needs a sequel to get everything right and designed for PC.

Some screenshots of the game (some may contain spoilers, didn't go through them):
https://steamcommunity.com/id/ImpalaPUA/screenshots/?appid=34010

reviewText:
Alpha Protocol is best, and perhaps most favorably described as different. It is the standard cover based third person shooter stealth game mixed in with a dialog system and storytelling mechanics that would put any RPG to shame.

The variety of choices and options in this game, and how they effect everything from the storyline to stat bonuses is truly inspired. It is one of the few games that can honestly claim that every game will play different and deliver on that promise.

The gameplay is fairly generic however and it is marred by seemingly unending wave of bugs that can turn an otherwise entertaining game into a frustrating exercise in teeth-grinding within minutes.

Despite it's obvious problems Alpha Protocol should be applauded for integrating choice and consequence into the gameplay in a way Bioware can only dream of. The mediocre gameplay and exorbitant amount of bugs however means this will never be the classic it was meant to be. Such a shame.

reviewText: I will be stoned for this, but Alpha Protocol is quite a lot like Deus Ex, only much better. Scratch what the reviews say about this game. Its an enjoyable action stealth game. Granted its a dog to play with keyboard & mouse but use a 360 controller and you are laughing all the way.

Visually its a nice looking game that runs well on most systems, only downside is that the textures can pop in, this happens on the kit out screen and in the safehouse usually, however if you remember Mass Effect was equally as bad for this!

reviewText:
This is an absoultely fantastic game with an amazing cast of characters and a fantastic plot that you can go through in a million different ways. Whenever bioware gibber incoherently about branching stories, Alpha Protocol is what they are trying to describe. It's a real tragety this game never got the attention it deserves because the way you can play through it and find a new way or outcome to everything you do is amazing.

Sega had Obsidian make the game and then sat on it for months and then refused to pay for bug testing and patching. Obsidian did what they could and it shows, but there are a few parts to the game that would have benefitted from a bit more polish. Some skills are massively overpowered and some aren't really worth even looking at. (Pistols and stealth let me break the game in half. Boss fights ended in literally two or three seconds because Thornton gained the power to stop time and put nine rounds into someones face at will) but beyond that there is something special here.

The characters and how they all interact are where the game really shines though, enemies can become friends, friends can become enemies, both might be either and you've just been listening to the wrong person, ♥♥♥♥ this person off or suck up to that person, it all brings benefits and has an actual effect on both the game (you get perks) and the plot. Take handler A on this mission and avoid a fight as he distracts the police with a fake radio alert elsewhere (I think, been awhile since I did that one) or take handler B. and get ready to fight the police only for him to level the trainstation by driving a train equipped with an anti aircraft flak cannon through and blasting everyone in tiny bits of meat. You will always see something new each playthrough.

reviewText: I originally purchased Alpha Protocol for PS3 when it came out a few years back.  After playing about midway through it I found it to be pretty boring and dropped it.  During the recent Steam sale I picked it up for PC and finished it today.  The story is very engaging and you meet a number of very interesting characters throughout the story.  The graphics are dated and the cover, shooting, and stealth are a little iffy at times.  However I have to say the game was very fun to play and had an original story with RPG elements unlike anything else I've played.  The dialogue choices alone make you want to replay certain sections to determine which responses may have alternate paths to take.  Again this one is primed for a replay and recommended to anyone that is willing to look past some of the unpolished parts and enjoy the game for what it is.

reviewText:
Alpha Protocol is one of those games that sneaks under the radar for most people but is actually a pretty decent game. It plays and feels like Mass Effect but with a spy setting. You play agent Mike Thorton who is recruited to a secret spy agency called Alpha Protocol and you find youself embroiled in a plot to kick off a new cold war which you need to stop. The strenghs of this game are in it's RPG elements. You can conversate with other characters via a dialogue sytem similar to Mass Effect and Dragons Age 2. Depending on what you say to a character can influence their opinion of you, which in turn can affect what they're willing to tell you. Get friendly enough with a character and they might help you later on in the game via intel or providing support on missions. The choices you make also have an impact later on in the game, for example going all gung-ho ona mission lead to more enemies in the next mission as security is increased.

The combat sections of the game is what lets it down. You can use various weapons which can be upgraded in your mission,as well as abilites you unlock as the game progresses. The combat does get repetetive after a while though an interesting mechanic is the ability to acquire intel before a mission which gives you advantages like reducing enemy numbers or a sniper rifle drop.

Another interesting feature is the intel you can collect on factions and individual characters. Instead of being useless filler information, this intel can be useful in giving you hints in how to get a character to like you in a conversation or the tactics they use in a fight should you need to fight them.

The Good:
- interaction with other characters is this games main strength as well as the many ways and options you have in dealing with other characters and in missions.
-levelling system is pretty good with each point gained in a skill conferring you a bonus of some sort.
-Weapons and body armor customization is pretty good and varied
-the intel feature is pretty good and is actually of use instead of being just filler

The Bad:
- combat isn't great and gets repetitive
-game is pretty buggy at times.(i found my character was getting stuck in the ground every now and again)

Overall this game is pretty good if a bit flawed. Worth picking up if you enjoy action-rpgs like Mass Effect and Dragons Age. 7/10

reviewText: So underrated. Yes, the combat kind of sucks (it's servicable, but is entirely consolized and a bit wonky at times), but the real reason to play this game is the dialogue system. It's rare enough for video games to get something as mundane as people talking right so when it does happen it's a bit of a revelation. Dialogue options not only give you bonuses and pay off in real ways that affect the plot, but they are also timed--so rather than allowing you to sit and mull over what your character should say you need to make snap judgements and live with the consequences of your decisions. The result is that talking to people becomes a form of combat all its own--something which is, admittedly, much more exciting than the more literal forms of combat the game throws at you, but which is revolutionary enough on its own to make the game worth playing. Plus the plot/dialogue are well written enough to mostly rise above their hodge-podge of spy tropes and cliches. An overlooked (if rough) gem.

reviewText:
Alpha Protocol is a 3rd person RPG game made by Obsidian Entertainment. You play as Michael Thorton, an agent with a top secret branch of the CIA.

I can not speak highly enough about this game. Yes it does have some issues which I will get to in a bit but overal this game is amazing and very much worth your time if you are interested in the RPG genre. Lets start off with the pro's for this game.

Gameplay: You have 3 options for how to play the game right out of the gate. You can play as either a complete stealth style never being noticed by anyone. A middle of the road style where you use stealth to take out your enemys. Also an FPS style in which you go in guns blazing with no regard for stealth at all. This alone opens up many hours of replayability and is something I personally have not seen very often.

Customization: Just about everything about your character, except general looks, can be customized. Your weapons, what gear you take with you, and your armor or lack there of are all fully customizable giving you a plethora of options for each misson you go on.

Dialogue: The dialogue system is top notch giving you multiple options for how you want to respond, some of which are very entertaining. This also leads into a reputation and romance system that is very well developed for characters that actually make you care about them on some level.

Impact: This is probably the most important part, at least for me. The decisions you make in game, who you talk to, how you handle each situation, all matter a great deal in this game. Your choices have consequences and you have to carefully consider what you want to say, how to say it, and what to do at any given moment.

Now  lets touch on the negatives for this game, and yes, sadly there are a few.

AI: The enemies in Alpha Protocol are not the best out there. The can be rather predictable at times and glitch out. That being said it is not game breaking in any way and personally it didn't bother me all that much.

Combat: Alpha Protocol is first and foremost a console game. It was ported over to the PC and as such has a combat system that at times can feel clunky and drive you nuts. Once you get used to it though you can get through the game just fine.

Hacking: There really is no other way to say it, the hacking minigame in Alpha Protocol is absolutly terrible. It really could have used an overhaul but it sadly never came.

Bugs: There are a few other bugs in the game some of which can be quite annoying but I personally never experienced anything to dramatic or game  breaking.

Graphics: This was a console game that is pretty old at this point and was ported over to the PC. The graphics are not top tier yet at the same time I have seen a LOT worse out there.

TLDR: Alpha Protocol  is a great game very much worth the asking price and even more so if you can get it on sale. 7/10

reviewText:
There is always that game. The game most people know is good, but never played. Alpha Protocol can definitively be put in that category for a lot of people.

For the others, who actually played it, ask them what is the best spy game they played, and a lot of them will probably mention Alpha Protocol. Alpha Protocol is a lot less known than franchises suchs as MGS or Splinter Cell, which spawned multiple games, but it does a lot of things rights all while maintining a pretty realist setting.

You see, Alpha Protocol isn't just your random stealth game. In its story telling and character developpement, it's a lot closer to a RPG. The story follows the main protagonist as he gets recruited into an secret agency working for the US goverment. After training and a few missions, for some reasons I won't explain, he is forced to go rogue, and work on unraveling the conspiracy which put him in that situation all while avoiding being hunted by his former colleagues. On the way he will meet numerous allies and ennemies, and take part in a lot operations in various countries until the thrilling conclusion of the story.

But you see, even if I wasn't willingly leaving the details of the story vague, Alpha Protocol is a game where your decisions really matters. Who you will befriend, the ennemies you make, who gets to live or die, is all up to you via the decisions of your character. Dialogues often leave you a limited time to answer when you are talked to. So you need to respond in a pretty quick and instinctive manner. While some people may complain it's a bad idea, especially without a way to savescum easyly, I personnally find it gives the story a more organic feel. It does help the whole cast of character is really well done. Most of them have some pretty complex stories behind them, and their own psychology. Psychology, as such, is important when dealing with others. You need to understand the kind of person you're talking to and act accordingly. The character of Frank Heck, in particular, has become a fan favorite.
The game has multiple endings, some being pretty amazing, like joining forces with the bad" guy(s)
date: and even betraying them just afterward to take over. Something which isn't seen pretty often in games.\n\nAs for the gameplay

reviewText: I was impressed by the depth of story and dialogue choices in this game, and how the approach you take with people will have an impact on their impressions of you, and also that there are different effects based on what you choose. It's also one of the few games I've seen where having a low reputation with some people can actually work in your favor, if you prefer not to cater to everyone. The combat is fun and as for the character you have a lot of different skills to develop how you like; you can focus more on stealth or go hand to hand, or choose from pistols, SMGs, shotguns, or assault rifles. There are diffferent types of each weapon class with different stats and the same goes for armor; plus, all of the above can be customized with a variety of parts you can buy to improve the weapon or armor abilities further. If you played and liked Mass Effect and/or Deus Ex, you would probably enjoy this too.

reviewText:
Alpha Protocol, more accurately the critical response thereto, is a monument to games journalisms’ need for art-house institutions willing to judge games on non-commercial, non-standard merits. Considering Alpha Protocol as one considers most AAA-titles reveals a failed experiment: a reactive plot with inconsistent characters, gunplay that doesn’t quite land, unbalanced skill-trees that result in a clear hierarchy of character builds, and a floundering finale. These properties are, in some ways, Obsidian’s hallmark: since KOTOR2 and NWN2 the studio (my personal favourite working studio) has been plagued with releasing inconsistent products. In some ways, Alpha Protocol is the worst offender: there are some marring bugs that were never fixed which can lead to very flawed plays. Despite the above mentioned issues—even the slightly bland story and inconsistent characters—I’ve played through Alpha Protocol three times and enjoyed each pass.

Obsidian remind me of a quote from Tony Kushner (American dramatist most famous for Angels in America): Kushner distinguishes between two types of artists, “the ones who ask small questions but give great answers and the ones who ask huge questions and often, as a consequence of the ambitiousness of their questioning, fail to give good answers”. Kushner holds that both are necessary, and I agree with him; Obsidian and their works should be treated as the second category. They ask huge questions about RPG design, and though they fail, the questions themselves are both a merit and a necessity.
Alpha Protocol questions the very foundations of RPGs: it is not science fiction or fantasy, it has a branching plot in which the player is almost fifth business instead of universal saviour, and there is no party. Spies, turncoats, flashbacks take you on a global adventure that feels, ultimately, small: this isn’t fate of the galaxy (KOTOR) or fate of the Great Wheel (NWN2) stuff. We have a relatively localized plot that, while slightly bland and riddled with some forgettable characters, unfolds organically and persuasively. Everything feels like it happens for a reason, and you never question your character’s role in it; the game is quite good at being reactive (or at least appearing so, and illusion is everything) and that’s the whole goal.

And on the merit of its questions, I think Alpha Protocol is an important game. It asks: does an RPG need a party? (no); can it deal with slightly smaller stakes? (yes); can it play like an action game instead of an excel simulator? (yes), etc. I would never absolve Alpha Protocol of its bugs or failures—one particular bug causes all enemies on a map to disappear, which can make some areas of the game unforgivably bland, until you figure out that it’s a bug you can correct by shutting down and reloading, which is still unacceptable—but regardless I recommend the game as a glimpse of what RPGs could be like. And, honestly, the bugs aren’t that bad; if you’ve made your way through STALKER, you’ve played far worse on that front.

reviewText:
Another half-baked game from Obsidian.

The dialogue system is good. The story is more or less intriguing. But the rest is complete crap.

Movement is clunky. Camera is bad. Shooting is horrible. And melee is even worse. Character development system is too primitive. Locations are too linear and provide almost no variety in walkthrough. Enemies are super dumb, but have a great aim and spot you immediately (played on hard). And if you thought you could bear all that because it's a stealth game - no, you can't. There are moments when the game throws enemies at you and the only way to deal with them is a direct confrontation.

If you want a spy game, play Splinter Cell or No One Lives Forever. If you want an RPG/shooter, play Mass Effect. If you want cyberpank stealth/shooter, play Deus Ex. Alpha Protocol tries to be everything at once and fails miserably.

reviewText:
This game. It is fun. It can also be frustrating.

What is fun? Why is it fun?

You're a super secret spy sent by America to open a can of whoop ♥♥♥ on terrorists and other ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s.

You got guns. They're customizable and ♥♥♥♥. You choose which kinds of guns you want to use on which kind of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.

But hey, if you don't like guns, you can put skill points into martial arts and karate chop those mother ♥♥♥♥ers instead.

You see this game seems like an action game. It is. But it is also an rpg. You have multiple differerent skills that you can put points into when you level up. So you can choose what type of bad ♥♥♥ super secret agent you want to be. Want to run around the whole time shooting ♥♥♥♥ers in the face with a shotgun? Whatever man do what you want. But a little side note, the combat mechanics isn't exactly straightforward. In this sense it's more like an rpg. When you shoot a guy, the game calculates hit percentages and crits and ♥♥♥♥ like that. So when you line up your scoped pistol to the face of a guy three feet away from you who miraculously hasn't seen you yet, point it straight between that ♥♥♥♥ing dudes eyes, you pull the trigger...then somehow find out you missed and the dude has just stopped being blind long enough to riddle your ♥♥♥ with bullets. Yeah well, that's the game telling you to go ♥♥♥♥ yourself. So just keep that in mind.

But really the best part of the game is talking to people. Through your super spy social skills, you can choose things like whether or not you want to kill a guy. Or if you want to be an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, then be an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Seriously you choose how you want to behave or make important story decisions through dialogue. Also if you're super suave (or not) you could ♥♥♥♥ most of the chicks in this game. I myself ♥♥♥♥ed two chicks, however I probably could have had sex with another one, but I turned her down because I didn't think it was fair to the others. I'll check that out in my next playthough though.

With that all being said, this game can be a fun game. However, the frustrating part comes into play with this games glitches. I've probably replayed levels over and over more than I should have because of these glitches. Sometimes after dying and starting at a checkpoint, it seems that every guard decides to just get up and ♥♥♥♥ing leave, with me running around not knowing what to do because every single guard decided to go on a lunch break. There are other random glitches that you will undoubtedly encounter during your time as America's super awesome spy.

But I must say that however glitchy this game can be, it is not as bad as I was lead to believe before I bought it. Is this game fun? Yes. Is it frustrating? Yes. Is it more frustrating than fun? No. Is it worth 15 bucks? Maybe, but definitely worth 10 bucks. So I recommend you buying this game on sale at 10 bucks or under. Now excuse me while I replay this game and try to have sex with all three chicks.

reviewText: Alpha Protocol doesn't have stellar gameplay as far as stealth-action goes, but I found the thorough amount of dialogue options throughout the game made up for this. reviewText: After playing other games since finishing Alpha Protocol, I keep wishing those that boast a great conversation and choice system would look towards this game as a way to do it well. Possibly the best thing about the game that at best is a flawed gem, there's no doubt that it is a gem, so long as you're willing to look past just how flawed it is.\n\nMake no mistake, the whole game feels clunky, almost as if it was designed after all its characters, plot and the flow-chart-requiring choice system was implemented. It features that bizarre aspect of playing better the further in you get as you put points into your RPG'd character. That said, it does feel like catering to every aspect of a spy-in-fiction available, from sauvé Bond-esque conversationalist, cool-gadget user and pistol-preferring gentleman, to the Bourne beat the crap outta them!" specialist in martial arts. It's just a shame that while you're developing these

This was an OK experience. I like to think of AP as a cross between Mass Effect & Batman Arkham...Maybe even Deus Ex!

If you're REALLY considering reading this whole review, let me tell you why

AS A STEALTH GAME
First of all, gameplay is mostly stealthy. That is: Hiding, waiting for enemies to have their backs turned, then kill them without being detected. That is pretty cool. But the feel of the rest of the gameplay just didn't do it for me. Combat kind of blows. It's just not FLUID at all and the amount of control feels like I'm prodding a pregnant cow. For everything it can offer, I would rather be playing a Batman Arkham game when said and done. If you're looking for a Stealth game, do not buy this game, go buy Arkham Asylum.

reviewText: An interesting take on an espionage game, Alpha Protocol manages to keep you on your toes for most of its story, with a plot straight out of a Bourne movie. The game has some pacing problems but it gives you an impressive amount of freedom and still wraps things up satisfyingly. The characters are refreshing and the innovative conversation mechanics (limited time to choose your answer) force you to actually think about your replies. Sadly, the gameplay is very aracade-styled, with the shooting elements completely broken in your favor when using a mouse and a keyboard. Still, it deserves to be played as one of the few true espionage RPGs.

reviewText: What do I say about this game? It's not particularly well done, but the writing is excellent. It's a second-rate console port, but it's suprisingly talky and interesting at times. There's a fair share of unpatched bugs, and might run like ♥♥♥ on your system, but if it works, it's pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ immersive and fun to play. The weapons handle like ♥♥♥ and you're going to hate the ♥♥♥♥ out of them at first, but that merely is a thing that's done to demonstrate just how awesomely broken the stealth system is in your favor. To summarize, this is basically an unrefined project that got booted out the door, yet another hallmark of Obsidian's approach to making games, but most of it is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ awesome and you might not even notice the bugs. You know, right up until they stop you from completing a mission dead in your tracks.\n\nOh, and ♥♥♥♥ computer hacking.

reviewText:
Fantastic action/rpg that was plagued with poor press on release. It's basically like a modern day james bond, with all the womanising and over-the-top action one would expect. The shooting mechanics feel a little 'light', similar to mass effect's gunplay, but not as bad.

The game can be played any way you like, lethal or non-lethal, run and gun or stealthy, but have little bearing on the overall outcome. If you're looking for a hardcore stealth/espionage game like metal gear solid or splinter cell, it doesn't really deliver.

Intriguing storry, great voice acting (featuring Jim Cummings aka Minsc) and just a satisfying singleplayer experience overall.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Alpha Protocol is one of the few games I wish I'd never played, because I'd still be able to experience it for the first time.

Everything you do in this game has consequences, from conversations with the other characters to how you carry out your missions. There are whole missions you can miss out on depending on how much intel you gather, and characters that you may never meet face to face. The story is non-linear, with different outcomes and events depending on which order you complete the main hubs in.

If, like me, you're a sucker for story in games and are willing to put up with slightly clunky gameplay, give this one a try. The story, settings and characters are all fantastic, and the audio design is among the best of any game I've played. Overall, it definitely places in my top five favorite games of all time.

reviewText: Alpha Protocol is hands down one of the best spy and espionage games on the PC. It kind of makes you feel like Jason Bourne. The interactive story provides satisfaction in knowing you are actually a part of the outcome and all of your actions have consequences. In addition, the timed responses mean that all conversations remain fluid and believable. The perk system provides persona customization primarily between stealth or run and gun. There is a money collection system for buying weapons, armor, and accessories through the black market to enhance your chosen perks. The aiming system was biggest weakness, the enemy AI could have been improved, and the bosses seemed overpowered, but overall there was really very few issues with the gameplay, and the execution is top notch. The game also offers a lot of replayability due to its diverse story paths. This is a must buy.

reviewText:
There's so much to say about this game.

On the one hand, it's an Obsidian game, so it's glitchy as all hell. Furthermore, the game engine really never feels as though it's completely up to the task of pulling off all of what a game like this should offer. For as much freedom as the character-building and combat offer, the game engine really places some unfortunate restrictions on you at times. Level traversal is very linear, and you're too often restricted to one very questionable path through areas.

That said, this game is freaking AWESOME. The combat is really satisfying, and the level of freedom that you have in making or breaking relationships with your various contacts is nothing short of intriguing. I daresay that the game reminds me of Deadly Premonition in terms of its ambition in that it takes some interesting approaches to certain game elements, but all of it would be so much more satisfying in a more competently-build game.

Still, I can't recommend this game enough. Definitely a must-play.

reviewText:
The guy is an ♥♥♥ but the game is pretty fun.

This game is pretty unique in the sense that your choices really do matter. Lots of games claim that choices matter, but ultimately, you can find a way to get the best of both worlds. That is not true in this game. Your choices have real consequences, and it makes the game feel more realistic. In a situation like this, not everybody is going to get out alive, the allies you make might be unexpected, and your decisions will impact others. That's what I really appreciated about this game.

Yes there is a lot of outdated gameplay. Many games have taken the flaws of this game and improved them so they don't exist anymore. There might be a few frustrating moments or times where you say, how the hell did that even happen"

reviewText: An interesting take on an espionage game, Alpha Protocol manages to keep you on your toes for most of its story, with a plot straight out of a Bourne movie. The game has some pacing problems but it gives you an impressive amount of freedom and still wraps things up satisfyingly. The characters are refreshing and the innovative conversation mechanics (limited time to choose your answer) force you to actually think about your replies. Sadly, the gameplay is very aracade-styled, with the shooting elements completely broken in your favor when using a mouse and a keyboard. Still, it deserves to be played as one of the few true espionage RPGs.

reviewText:
The guy is an ♥♥♥ but the game is pretty fun.

This game is pretty unique in the sense that your choices really do matter. Lots of games claim that choices matter, but ultimately, you can find a way to get the best of both worlds. That is not true in this game. Your choices have real consequences, and it makes the game feel more realistic. In a situation like this, not everybody is going to get out alive, the allies you make might be unexpected, and your decisions will impact others. That's what I really appreciated about this game.

Yes there is a lot of outdated gameplay. Many games have taken the flaws of this game and improved them so they don't exist anymore. There might be a few frustrating moments or times where you say, how the hell did that even happen"

reviewText:
There's so much to say about this game.

On the one hand, it's an Obsidian game, so it's glitchy as all hell. Furthermore, the game engine really never feels as though it's completely up to the task of pulling off all of what a game like this should offer. For as much freedom as the character-building and combat offer, the game engine really places some unfortunate restrictions on you at times. Level traversal is very linear, and you're too often restricted to one very questionable path through areas.

That said, this game is freaking AWESOME. The combat is really satisfying, and the level of freedom that you have in making or breaking relationships with your various contacts is nothing short of intriguing. I daresay that the game reminds me of Deadly Premonition in terms of its ambition in that it takes some interesting approaches to certain game elements, but all of it would be so much more satisfying in a more competently-build game.

Still, I can't recommend this game enough. Definitely a must-play.

Grr... my review got eaten just as I finished it. ;_;

I'll try to summarize what I wrote...

The main character is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ spy who has to unmask conspiracy things involving terrorism and evil corporations. reviewText:
I thoroughly recommend this game.

Despite all its flaws, glitches and errors (of which there are a few) this game is tremendous fun. The RPG side is not well fleshed out but it still has a nice sense of fulfilment to it. The discussion tree is vast with so many choices to go through, I suspect this game can be different every time through up to 4 maybe 5 playthrough’s (if you can stick it out that long).

The characters and story are great and very well fleshed out. I loved finding out things about everyone I met and the world in general around the action seemed deep and rich as well. As for the combat it was alright, for an RPG it was fantastic, for an action game it was average at best. The Ai is either amazing or so stupid it ignores being shot. I found little use for the gadgets but I loved using some of the skills.

As for progression when you gain enough XP you level up and in doing so can add to a number of espionage/weapon skills. You will probably want to specialise in one weapon, doing more than that means you can fill out the full skill tree. Side note: pistol is OP.

If this game is on sale you should pick it up, not recommended at full price unless you love the concept, too many glitches to really justify though.

Have fun ^_^

reviewText:
Alpha Protocol is an interesting TPS developed by Obsidian Entertainment. In order to define its genre I'd say it's an action-RPG. You level up throughout the game which allows you to select from various perks. I, personally, went with pistols as weapon specialisation along with stealth which made my gameplay a lot of fun - I have to admit, though, combat is not exactly refined and the boss battle did not leave much room for stealth which was a disappointment.

Alpha Protocol offers you choices during the dialogues. As opposed to Mass Effect there's no indication whether or not your choices are good (no Paragon and Renegade approach) and interestingly conversations are timed so you need to pick an answer rather quickly. Making the bad decisions can have dire consequences at the end of the game which has some surprises in store for you.

While somewhat mediocre, Alpha Protocol has its exciting moments and those in favour of the genre should pick this up. I believe its metascore of 72/100 is not really justified.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A Flawed Masterpiece

From the get-go: the gameplay is TERRIBLE. It's simply awful; animations are terrible, enemy AI is either ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ or omniscient, the mini-games scale poorly to the point of being nearly completely broken; fortunately once you learn how to exploit it it is incredibly easy.

The gameplay however is the flawed part.

The plot, however, is simply amazing. I'm not referring simply to the story. It's how it plays out that is simply amazing. When most games claim that actions have consequences they usually mean that you merely get to choose some buttons at the end and a pat on the back because you killed few or no people.

With Alpha Protocol this is not the case. Everything you do changes everything around you. Every single gameplay can be different merely because of how you chose to react to certain people. And the NPCs react to who you are to the point of some being able to figure you out because of your past actions and reputation.

This even reflects itself in the gameplay where there are perks related to your play style but also how you roleplay. Basically it's possible to be (somewhat) uniquely rewarded for all possible play styles. Are you a pacifist? Kill everyone? Mix and match? Are you nice to people? Irreverent? Random? You'll be rewarded.

That's why it's a masterpiece. Play it twice and you'll start to see it. From then on you'll start seeing how every little detail is a part of something bigger and a single playthrough is not enough to experience the entire plot or even the full extent of possibilities within the game itself.

This of couse only applies to people who actually like games with a plot. If you're the run & gun type to whom games are merely violence porn" and you zone out if someone doesn't get shabbed every 45 seconds then don't even buy this since it'll just be fodder for you to "write" a terrible review.

I blame SEGA for rushing this."

reviewText:
This game is worth it, but it will disappoint you, and possibly frustrate you.

As many have said, the dialogue system and character interaction are very well done. The perk system is cool, and the skills system is decent. And the story (just done first few missions) is spy-ish.

I liked the buy the intel, the dossiers, and the reading it entails (makes it feel more grounded in espionage than just first person shooting). The graphics are good (including the character details when talking, etc). I liked the mini-games (which simulate hacking, lockpicking and eletronic lock bypassing) which are based on observation puzzles against a clock.

You will be disappointed by the animations which are a bit stiff but not bad. The controls (because of a possible poor console port) seem a tiny bit sluggish. You will become a little bit annoyed at the hacking mini-game because of the wildly poor mouse response to it.

And finally, you might become ANGERED by the too frequent (for me at least) crash glitch which occurs against walls and corners, especially when stealthing which you will want to do a lot because, y'know you are a spy.
So when your character jams permanently into an invisible wall-terrain join, just seconds before the checkpoint for the nth time, you will WANT to SMASH your pc screen. DON'T. Just turn off the game. and come back to it later. You will enjoy it again after a break....and hopefully the bug won't hit you so maliciously the next time.

reviewText:
Seriously underrated game.  This is an RPG game, not a purely action game, so you need to level up and work on advancing your skills and customizing your character.  If you expect traditional action gameplay, you'll be disappointed.  But as an RPG, it's a lot of fun, and the espionage settting is a fun change of pace from the usual sword-and-board Tolkien cut-and-pasted drivel that most game makers seem to think we want in our role playing games.

The game is very ambitious, though you do have to be tolerant of some of relatively rough production values.  OK, very rough production values.  I guess that's why most people hate the game.  But if you are the kind of player who wants a game where your decisions really do impact the gameplay, the story, and the future missions, this is a great game because it delivers in that department.  Mass Effect has more polish, and better gameplay, but really, at the end of the day, all your decisions do is change a few seconds worth of cut scene at the end.   The Telltale Walking Dead games love to tease you with the choice between saving one character or another.  But then, no matter who you save, they end up dying a few minutes later.  Your decisions simply don't matter in most games.  But in Alpha Protocol, the story can change dramatically from one playthrough to the next in a way that most games still can't compete with.

And, sadly, it's still one of the only non-sci-fi, non-fantasy RPGs out there.

This is an excellent game. I haven't had this much fun sneaking around in a long time.  Story is very good.  Gameplay is amazing.  I'm not completely done with it, but I'm probably going to replay it again as soon as its done.

Its essentially all the best parts of the Metal Gear Solid games, but without all the crazy japanese stuff. (Sometimes I like crazy japanese stuff, like enemies who are genetically merged with wasps, but its also nice to have a great stealth game thats a tad more serious).

10/10   This is one of the best stealth/spy/espionage games ever.

reviewText:
A truly underrated title. It has a really great conversation system, interesting characters, and excellent leveling up and customization, allowing you to go through the game with different builds.

It is not, however, without its flaws. The gameplay controls are not very responsive. For a game looks and feels like it should be a third person shooter, the actual shooting mechanic is very poor. The stealth mechanics are better than the shooting, but Splinter Cell this is not. And it a few mandatory boss fights, which are of course terrible in this style of game.

In fact, the game is very similar to Deus Ex: Human Revolution. They certainly both occupy the same genre of Steath/Action/RPG. The biggest difference is that DXHR has better gameplay, but far worse plot and character. Alpha Protocol has much better characters, plot, and dialogue/choices, but the gameplay is less polished.


That said, if you enjoy games with well written characters, interesting choices, and one of the best conversation systems ever in any RPG, then you'll enjoy Alpha Protocol.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Alpha Protocol is hands down one of the best spy and espionage games on the PC. It kind of makes you feel like Jason Bourne. The interactive story provides satisfaction in knowing you are actually a part of the outcome and all of your actions have consequences. In addition, the timed responses mean that all conversations remain fluid and believable. The perk system provides persona customization primarily between stealth or run and gun. There is a money collection system for buying weapons, armor, and accessories through the black market to enhance your chosen perks. The aiming system was biggest weakness, the enemy AI could have been improved, and the bosses seemed overpowered, but overall there was really very few issues with the gameplay, and the execution is top notch. The game also offers a lot of replayability due to its diverse story paths. This is a must buy.

reviewText:
I gave this gem a miss when it first came out, AFAICR because the reviews were quite off-putting. Having finally played it, I can't think why.

This is a game in the spirit of Deus Ex, and for the most part, it pulls it off.
- no fundamentally different / unique aproaches to mission (you can sneak, go in guns blazing or mix & match)
- no adventure-style missions, where you just walk around in your civvies and talk to people, maybe solve a puzzle or two. There are a few talking-only missions (and one exception from the rule).
+ dialogue, reputation and dossier system works really well, even though you only get a few choices at each juncture.
+ lots of meaningful choices, some with more impact, some with less, some more obvious, others less so. The story tree must be enormous, yet the game never gives you a line that doesn't fit what you did three missions back. This thing is really well written.
+ replayability looking good, though I've only done one run.
+ console roots are unmistakable, but it works fine on Windows.

It's not Deus Ex (not sure if one can surpass that), and it's not Human Revolution either (didn't have the budget), but it isn't Invisible War either. Recommended.

reviewText:
Mike: I'm a spy.
Scarlet: (laugh) Did this line ever worked?
Mike: I don't know, are you impressed?
Scarlet: No.
Mike: Then never.
― Mission: Picking Up. Status: Failed ;)

Obsidian Entertainment. Interplay Entertainment. Black Isle Studios. Different varieties and the same common, great story - the best RPG's ever. And probably the last title, which I have not played - Alpha Protocol.

After 23h (two full runs):
PROS
+ three JB styles - Bond, Bourne, Bauer
+ Agent History styles & Advance for 2nd run...
+ ...resulting different game's style during a mission
+ full customization - weapons, gears, armors, beards and mustaches ;)
+ dialogue system
+ locations and their structure
+ very nice NPC's
+ reputation and romances (in 007 style [or Buck from KillBill ;P] My name's Mike, and I'm here to give you my pike.)
+ nice character development
+ last, but MOST important - REAL choices and consequences in a REAL non-linear storyline

CONS
- enemies AI
- flawed combat system
- and terrifying MASS of smaller and larger bugs sometimes completely ruining all the pros...
- EDIT: somehow I forgot about the terrible, massacred-my-eyes, inhumanely against human rights... hacking.


Subjective rate: A+ for non-linear choices and consequences, and for that you really feel like a secret agent/spy/mercenary in international intrigue
B- or C+ for story AND technical side
D or F only for technical side
F+atality for hacking style

Really, I have no clue why released to market as terribly technically underdeveloped game like this. And what the strangest thing - despite all the bugs... story is complete and consistent. Whatever you do, whatever you choose - there are no gaps as in the case of (for example another Obsidian) Fallout: New Vegas.

Strange. This game is no longer count on any patches, but surely it deserves a sequel, with the same dose of juicy RPG AND with normal engine, without the dramatic novice programmer's mistakes.

reviewText:
It's a tough call to give this a thumbs up or not. For the longest time it would have been a thumbs down. However I had some free time not too long ago and decided to power through the intro and I got hooked.

The gameplay isn't all that great (if not outright bad), but the story/dialogue redeemed the game for me. Once I leveled up a bit, and learned how to exploit the game mechanics the game clicked for me. Maxed out stealth and got the 5 shot multishot for pistols. Once I did that I could just focus on enjoying the story and stealth through about 90% of the game.

The best part of the game, and the part I am giving a positive review for, is the story/dialogue/writing. Your choices matter, your relationships matter, the order you do missions matter, sometimes even your choice of attire matter (well once anyway). I haven't played the game twice, but there were multiple ways to accomplish things, multiple ways to ♥♥♥♥ people off, or win them over.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A few words: Jolly good fun!!!

Where to start??? A lot of choices, a lot of characters, a cool (if kinda campy) espionage story, what's not to like???

The way they handle choices is very brilliant. It's up to you whether you want to be a suave spy a la James bond or cold combat pragmatist a la Jason Bourne who punch the hell out of anyone dare to deter you from your objective. Choices matter. Some characters may like you, some may hate you. But what I like it isn't about good or bad choices. All choices have its own advantages and disadvantages. By threatening some informant you may get discount on weapons but he will alert the local government, blackmailing a local triad boss may get you a large sums of money but you lost his support, etc. There're also a lot of small details, such as dialog change based on where you start your mission first. Love this small care to details.

There are also a lot of characters, some of them become your handler (your mission intel guy) and give you passive bonus, such as lowering the chance for your enemy to detect you or increasing your endurance. Sadly most of the time you'll be guided by Mina (your default handler) with few option to change handler in several missions. The problem with a lot of character is most of the character aren't really fleshed out. Some of them are really interesting but their story end up abruptly without closure about who's this guy really is or who the hell they work for, etc. Such a shame, really.

And the story!!! Hell yeah it's your typical espionage story, about deception, betrayal, and controversial topic. What's make this game special is the way the story handled. A lot of your choices will affect the story. The story is immensely branching, many of your choices will create a completely different way the even unfolds and how the game will end. It's up to you whether you want to play a game about revenge, about patriotic spirit, or maybe you can gain something from all the conflicts? Who knows, eh? So what are you waiting for??? Play this game!!!

reviewText: Being able to make choices in a game is a big deal these days. It's just a shame few do it well. And out of those few that manage it, Alpha Protocol stands tall as the prime example. The gameplay may be archaic at best and broken at worst but it crafts an excellent techno-thriller with a well thought out world and invites you to spin it how you want. Whereas an average game would give you a bonus if you made someone your friend, Alpha Protocol may reward you by angering someone so much that their hatred of you clouds their judgement. Whereas a normal game makes you choose a side, Alpha Protocol invites you to play multiple sides, playing them off against each other leaving the remaining allies ripe for a final, easy betrayal.\n\nIf you like games that let you truly get involved in their storylines and don't ever make you think how 'this choice would actually work in a video game', play this. Seriously, there's not really another game that has done choices as well.

reviewText:
This game is seriously ♥♥♥♥ing amazing in some very specific ways, and unfortunately very mediocre in many others. If you can get past the game mechanics, which are annoying at best, you encounter one of the best written and most reactive games I have ever played. Every action you take and how you conduct yourself in every conversation has a cascading effect on how events in the game unfold and how everyone else responds to you.

Non spoilery example: There is a boss that, depending on how you act, you can kill roughly halfway through the game, right near the end of the game, have another boss kill him near the end of the game, or have him kill another boss for you near the end of the game.

This is the first and only game I have ever played where there truly was no best path through the game. You make choices, and your choices have consequences, but every path you take through the world of international espionage is rewarded in some way, so if you want to be Jason Bourne, cold and professional, you can. You can also be Sterling Archer, ♥♥♥♥up spy extraordinairre and set off every alarm, loudly kill every bad guy, and attempt to sweet talk every female you encounter.

reviewText:
This is a tough one to review. I'm going to try and assert what this game is trying to be, followed by what it actually is.

Alpha Protocol is advertised as espionage game with RPG elements, this may give potential buyers the idea that the level of sneaking involved is reminiscent to that of the elder Splinter Cell series, but unfortunately this is far from true. The mechanics in Alpha Protocol limit you to basic climbing, basic hand-to-hand combat and you should expect that most sneaking will consist of simply taking cover behind objects to break the line of sight, which is rather disappointing. However, the RPG elements in Alpha Protocol are nifty and interesting, they can greatly influence the game and the modifications you make will definitely be an asset to your personal skills and gameplay.

Lastly, spy thrillers usually involve conspiracies or dirty gritty stories, and Alpha Protocol does this in a somewhat decent way. Don't get me wrong there, the story is pretty interesting and involves the player traveling to diverse locations and meeting different people, but the presentation of the story is lacking.

With that in mind, my last important note and a lot of the justified criticism for this game can be mentioned shortly and firmly: this game should not have been released yet. Alpha Protocol is very buggy, feels unpolished and in overall these things killed what would have been a great experience. My verdict: only buy this if it's on sale, a price tag of  €5,- would be as far as I'd go. Of course, one might pay more if he or she is not annoyed by bad character animations, odd NPC behavior, graphics glitches and event triggers that do not work as intended. For reference, you can look up Voidhead's 'Alpha Protocol - bugs, glitches and annoyances' video on YouTube.

reviewText:
Rating 8.5/10
Overview: Underrated RPG

The Good:

+ What really sets Alpha Protocol apart from almost every other RPG out there is that EVERY choice you make influences the story or your character in some way. The order in which you play missions, the choices you make in the game, how you speak to people...all of it has a major or minor effect in how the story and missions play out. There is no right or wrong answer, there is no good or evil, there is only your choices and the consequences that follow.

+ Character creation is identical to the first Mass Effect. As you level up you gain points to spend in a variety of categories. As you spend points in any particular category you gain passive and active abilities. You could play stealthy, guns blazing, maybe some close quarter combat, the game gives you plenty of options in how to develop your character

+ The game provides a lot of different perks depending on how you play. Pick enough locks and you will get a bonus to your lock picking skills. Get enough headshots and you gain a perk in accuracy etc. Almost everything you do in the game has some sort of perk associated with it.

+ Lots of items/weapons/armor/upgrades to further customize your character

+ Multiple endings depending on the choices you make.

+ Level design is solid, giving you multiple ways of completing certain objectives. My biggest gripe however is that the levels are a little too linear for my tastes. For a game that is all about choices I would have liked some more levels that are open ended.

+ The story and dialogue is well written and doesn't take itself too seriously given the subject matter. Obsidian wasn't afraid to have a lot of interesting characters either.

+ Surprisingly, on a technical level the graphics are very well done. Textures and characters are well detailed.

The Average


The AI can be very impressive at times. The enemies hide behind cover, duck and weave, try to flank you at times and in general act the way they are suppose to. This only highlights when enemies act completely stupid, running in the same spot, getting stuck behind cover, and in general seem to prefer being dead than alive.

Very noticeable texture load in when customizing your look or selecting weapons and armor. Some texture pop in when a level loads.

Certain bosses are very difficult to complete depending on what skills you invested in.

The game can be easily 'broken' if you invest in certain skills

The Bad

- The crouching animation is one of the worst animations I've seen in gaming

- There is an overall lack of polish in the game especially regarding the cover based shooting.

- The game can be especially frustrating in the beginning when you have very low skills and killing enemies is difficult.


Conclusion

I have completed this game many times on the xbox360 and looking at this game strictly from a RPG perspective  I think Alpha Protocol is one of the best RPG's around. One of the reasons why the game did so poorly is that most people were expecting a third person shooter with RPG elements like Mass Effect, instead Alpha Protocol is a full blown RPG that happens to be a third person shooter. As long as you realize this you will have a great time.

reviewText:
I forgot I didn't have a recommendation for this game because I pirated it years ago.

Anyway, the premise of the game is pretty awesome, and not really something done before, you're Micheal Thorton, a  bipolar and slightly psychopathic spy that gets betrayed by his own agenecy and has to go rogue to save the world. Well, more like save face for America, but close enough.

I'd go into praise about the gameplay here, but unfortunately Deus Ex: HR did almost everything this game did but better.  The stealth is wonky as ♥♥♥♥ (the developers probably realised this and literally made one of the skills make you go invisible the first time you are spotted) the combat trees are unbalanced, and worst of all there's level scaling, at the start of the game, people die when they are killed, and near the end russian gangsters are tanking headshots like they've been crocodil addicts their entire lives.

I briefing mentioned the protagonist's mental deffecientcies earlier, the dialogue system is sort of similar to mass effect, instead of picking what you are going to say, you instead pick an 'approach' such as being suave, joking, aggressive, etc. However, you don't know HOW WELL or how MUCH Micheal is going to go.  Cutting to the chase, Michael is ♥♥♥♥ing terrible at jokes, and is extremely violent and sadistic when given the chance.  To make things worse, being successful against certain NPCS tends to just mean picking one approach and staying with it instead of responding appropriately in a fluid converstational matter.  Of course, since it's an obsidian game, it's filled with a few glitches and probably missing 20% content.

All these terrible things being said about the game, it's definitely worth your time, there's some great scenes, and a couple of interesting characters, and some decent customization for your very own secret agent.

reviewText: I absolutely love this game! Despite all of it's bugs, animation problems, questionable level design, gameplay flaws (stealth system and shooting are truly horrible), it is one of those games, which give you a chance to LIVE the experience, not just shoot-kill-see-the-cat-scene. The plot and the approach to storytelling are amazing, the characters are really interesting; the dialog system is something similar to the one we've seen in Mass Effect, but it is more complex: there are no simply paragon/renegade/something_useless options, you have to find the dialog tactic for each of NPC you meet in this game. Strongly recommend this game to the fans of Obsidian titles and RPGs in general.

reviewText:
This is a very underrated stealth/action game that recieved a lot of crap when it first came out. If not for those early reviews I have no doubt this game would be rated at least 80-85 on metacritic. The main problem is that the developers tried to put everything into the game, so it doesnt nessesarily excell at any of them.

With that said, the game is very unique because of this as well. You're able to build social connections in the game, customize your armor and weapons, and go about missions however you like. You'll see the results and effects of how many people you kill or how many people see you once the mission is over. You even get a little terminal in the game that you can use for emailing other characters.

Overall it's a really good game, but it may take a bit to get used to the very strange shooting mechanics. Once you've jumped that hurdle you'll be gold.

reviewText:
Ignore the negative press. This is easily one of my favourite RPGs of the last generation. The sheer reactivity of the game is staggering, and the dialogue trees are second to none. The combat ain't Mass Effect. This is foremost a stat-driven RPG. Your gun will miss if you haven't put points into it. For some, that's unacceptable, but I never saw that as a problem.

Obsidian might be a flawed developer, but they're the best RPG maker in the biz.

reviewText: In Alpha Protocol, players control Michael Thorton, a young man with a chip on his shoulder who acts like a real bummer around his friends after his girlfriend left him for his uncontrollable flatulence problem. The game takes place over the course of a single night where Michael’s bros take him out for a night around town. This however isn’t just any night, for Michael’s friends decided to activate what they call the “Alpha Protocol”. The game reveals itself to be a visual novel dating sim where Michael Thorton’s friends pressure him to talk to young ladies, but only after talking to them about how alpha Michael is, and how much of a catch he would be. This goes on for a while as every eligible lady is turned off by Michael’s stench of sewage and rotten eggs. In the end, Michael comes to the epiphany that perhaps he should look for some ladies who also have trouble controlling their sphincters.\n\nThe moral of the game’s narrative is that perhaps being beta isn’t so bad.

reviewText:
Great game but it could have been so much more.

Good:
It's a spy shooter that let's you play the way you want, stealth, guns blazing, etc.  An RPG skill system can be used to bolster your play style, for example developing lock pickking, silent running, rifles, explosives, etc. Your choices in and out of combat give you influence with various characters and ultimately decide how the story unfolds and how the game ends.

Bad:
It was obviously dumbed down for consoles.
Some of the hacking mini games are annoying
Although the story is good, some of the choices are forced a la Mass Effect, choose who dies.
Worse, it does so, by commiting the ultimate gameplay sin where you win a battle, but lose in a cutscene.

Overall.  I love the game, but it could have been so much better.  As with many Obsidian games, the final execution just isn't quite there.  When will game makers understand that the real art isn't forcing us to choose who dies.  It's in allowing us to discover how to save both, or maybe not to be the hero and let them all die.  Still, highly worth playing.

reviewText:
Alpha Protocol is frequently overlooked but it's an RPG game made by Obsidian, which is enough in itself to justify a purchase, however unpolished you might think it is.

One interesting take on the genre is the conversation system, which gives general demeanours (suave, professional, etc.) for responses.  This can occasionally hide the intent of a choice in a way that reminded me of Mass Effect's conversation system.  However, you have limited time to respond in Alpha Protocol, which means you have to think on your feet during what's normally a passive situation.

Alpha Protocol presents a dynamic story in a way I don't remember seeing elsewhere.  Some games claim to provide branching storylines but this one genuinely varies impressively, which can lead to truly satisfying end results as you see the outcome of your choices.  You can become allies with one faction or turn them into enemies, trust someone or be completely suspicious of them, etc., depending on your mood.

The combat's a bit unbalanced and some skill trees break the game.  Still, I don't remember too many situations that were completely frustrating (but it's been a while since I played it).  I played in a somewhat stealthy way and the most annoying part was one particular boss, who seemed very unbalanced for my given player build (you'll know which one when you run into him!).  I was able to take him down eventually with some Brave Sir Robin-esque kiting.

Some reviews mention how buggy the game was.  I didn't hit any of these bugs, for what that's worth.  Your experience may be different if you're unlucky, I suppose.

If you're into RPGs with a bit of action then this is worth a go as it has interesting ideas and you can really affect the story in big ways.  Plus, it's an Obsidian game.  Did I mention that already?

reviewText:
I don't know why this game got panned. When I heard they were making an espionage action RPG with Mass-Effect conversation threads that you need to react to in real-time, I actually got tingly. But, then the reviews came out, and, shamefully, I listened.

However, I gave the game a chance recently (as it was on special), and sat and played through it until I got a yeast infection. This game is that kind of fun. It's not perfect, but what game is? It's the right mix of over-the-top spy action and RPG level-ups that everyone loves.

Get yourself a stick and a rag, and sit down to play this.

reviewText:
Despite it's flaws, this game is amazing.  Things get blown up, sexy men, shoot people, sexy ladies, you hack things, sneak around, oh and get some lovin from some sexy ladies.

There are a variety of ways you can play. Want to just jump right into the action, and mass rage at everyone? Okays, cool, you can do that.  Want to pull some martial arts out your pocket, and knock them senseless? Yeah. That'll work too. Want to sneak and be some wicked ninja? Right on!  (though stealth has some major 'game breaking' flaws for some).

The most interesting aspect of this game is the dialogue choices. You can choose from different styles (sauve, professional, joking, etc), which all affect how the fractions and individuals view you.  Getting them to hate you, or like you will have its benefits for you (such as an increase in endurance).  However, if one fraction favors you, you may have issues with those who oppose it- choose wisely!

The point? Must buy.

reviewText:
If you resign yourself to the fact that main character Michael Thorton is going to be a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ no matter what dialogue options you pick, this game is actually great fun. I started out playing it as a smug lunatic for the so-bad-it's-good dialogue and got legitimately sucked in part way through.

Sufficiently complex story to stay interested, fun characters, a lot of choices that actually matter and enough options for not only your playstyle, but also your allies and allegiance to make it feel like you're building up a character and exploring a world; rather than just completing missions to get to the end.

Also, a surprisingly funny game. Have Mike make an ♥♥♥ of himself, hang out with Steven Heck or just aggressively flirt with every female for plenty of laughs.

reviewText: One of the last games by Bioware and Obsidian that I've finished.  I'm a big fan of both companies.  Alpha Protocol isn't a bad game, though the plot is relatively uninspired and the dialogue is a little...wooden.  However, you can see glimpses of greatness here and there. Gameplay is very, VERY similar to Mass Effect with over-the-shoulder run and gun interspersed with cut scenes.  Even the skill system foreshadows the games to come.  In the end, if you like Mass Effect, you'll probably enjoy playing through.  Especially if you get it on sale.

The controls might be a bit rough around the edges at first, but once you level up and improve your combat skills the controls improve mightily as well.

reviewText: Alpha Protocol is the gaming equivalent of a homely girl with a heart of gold. She may not look that great in comparison to some of her sisters, nor will she entice many people with her odd quirks; however, once you get to know her she will blow you away with her razor sharp wit and give you some truly memorable conversations. Her incredible depth will make you learn more and more things about her even after playing through" her three times - leaving you yearning for more. She's in good company with Deus Ex and Vampire: The Masquerade in the sense that these gals have some serious quirks but are ultimately the dream girl at the end of film.\n\nShe may not be for everyone at face value but if you give her the chance she deserves you surely won't be disappointed."

reviewText:
8/10 - Very good game but without that much of replayability.

Is this game worth the purchase? Yes.
After all this time Obsidian got rid of most of the bugs so now the game experience is good.
If you want a mixture of rpg elements (a lot of them and with actual repercussions on the story) and decent cover-based shooter then this game is for you; also, completing the game nearly only with stealth and takedowns is possible or, if you want to be a gunblazing tankier bearded badass you can achieve it.
I completed the game in about 17 hours on normal using mostly the stealth+silenced pistol+takedowns approach so it can be less long if you like to shoot everything on sight with shotguns/assault rifles/gadgets.

And yes, you can get the girls in here.

sidenote: the pistol tree is pretty much op but, along with the stealth one, it's a must if you want to play the stealth approach.

reviewText: Frankly, I feel that Alpha Protocol has gotten a bum rap. In particular, my experience was that it was nowhere near as buggy, unpolished, or ugly as many reviews suggested. And similarly, it seemed like many reviews mistook it for an action game, a shooter in particular, which it is not. Rather, it is an RPG with real-time, semi-action-oriented combat and stealth gameplay modified in significant part by one's statistics, as one would expect from an RPG. It is admittedly on the short side for the genre, but the game is so thoroughly laced with choices and consequences that it should reward multiple replays. Practically everything you do can have consequences both short term (a new perk, some experience, loot you wouldn't have found otherwise, a different dialogue track) and long term (entirely new approaches to later missions, permanent NPC deaths, etc). I feel I got my $50 worth. It's nowhere near that price these days.

reviewText:
Alpha Protocol is a game not without flaws, some of which can be noticeable and frustrating. The gunplay is unpolished and for the most part not very enjoyable. Enemy AI can be inconsistent, especially when it comes to the stealth aspects of the game. Some of the in-game animations can be painful to watch (I get back pains just thinking about the sneak/crouch animation). It's also known to have its fair share of bugs and glitches.

Having said all that, Alpha Protocol is still a fantastic action-RPG that I absolutely adored. It all starts with the timed dialogue system which offers several choices and forces you to think fast and pay close attention to the characters on-screen. Just about every decision you make can have an impact on the game going forward and cause the story to branch off in noticably different directions. Combined with the ability to tackle levels in various orders (which in turn influences how the story unfolds), you could play the game multiple times and have each playthrough be unique. The amount of freedom you're given over the course of the game is huge and quite refreshing.

The writing and story-telling are also bright spots. The complex story is full of conspiracy, coverups and espionage. The numerous characters you'll encounter along the way are generally interesting and well-written, most of which have lengthy backstories that you might not be able to uncover in a single playthrough. It's the kind of quality work you'd expect from Obsidian.

And while the sneaking mechanics can be janky at times, going the stealth route is still a whole lot of fun. Executing non-lethal take-downs and maneuvering through levels quiety and undetected is a satisfying feeling. Focusing on stealth/pistol gameplay and playing the Sam Fisher role is the preferred way to go and helps improve the gameplay exponentially.

Given its flaws and inconsistencies, Alpha Protocol is (understandably) a game not everyone will enjoy. However, I feel that if you can look past its problems and appreciate the unique aspects of the game, you can really enjoy the product that Obsidian created. In my opinion it's one of the finer and most underrated RPGs of the last few years.

reviewText: Seeing as how i purchased this game for 2 dollars, this is actually a pretty decent game (storywise at least).  If you're a fan of games where your actions and choices have consequences, this game is for you.  Some of the decisions you make really do feel like some of the decisions people in inteliigence would actually make.  The decision points are never A = good B = bad and you don't really know how your decisions will completely effect the storyline.  The conversations in the game are also well done and feel very natural.  There is, unforunately one glaring problem, and that is that the combat is pretty awful.  Shooting is not skill based at all, and is reliant on how you level up your skills.  Also the inventory suffers horribly from consolization, and you are unable to map equipment to hotkeys, rather relying on a radial wheel (like you would use on a console).  So if you enjoy a decent story and dialogue get this game (was 2$), but don't expect anything great combatwise.

reviewText:
A game I both love and hate in equal measure. The combat is janky and unbalanced as all get out and animations/texture quality can be laughable at times. The hacking minigame is unspeakably awful.

It's also one of the finest modern RPGs from this generation. It far eclipses what Mass Effect tried to do in terms of it's dialogue system and how characters react to your actions. The dossier system actually ties back into the game and the options you're given rather than being extra lore reading. And the sheer amount of reactivity to your choices and the consequences that can result put Mass Effect to shame, causing genuinely different endings based on how you play - sometimes drastically different. There isn't a blue, red, or green light to be found.

The beginning takes patience to trudge through, but once you're past the Saudi Arabia hub the game begins to shine.

reviewText:
A bit buggy and clunky, but a damn fun Espionage RPG.  Plays roughly like Mass Effect would if you had no squad mates.

Story : A+

Overall B-

reviewText:
Alpha Protocol is a game not without flaws, some of which can be noticeable and frustrating. The gunplay is unpolished and for the most part not very enjoyable. Enemy AI can be inconsistent, especially when it comes to the stealth aspects of the game. Some of the in-game animations can be painful to watch (I get back pains just thinking about the sneak/crouch animation). It's also known to have its fair share of bugs and glitches.

Having said all that, Alpha Protocol is still a fantastic action-RPG that I absolutely adored. It all starts with the timed dialogue system which offers several choices and forces you to think fast and pay close attention to the characters on-screen. Just about every decision you make can have an impact on the game going forward and cause the story to branch off in noticably different directions. Combined with the ability to tackle levels in various orders (which in turn influences how the story unfolds), you could play the game multiple times and have each playthrough be unique. The amount of freedom you're given over the course of the game is huge and quite refreshing.

The writing and story-telling are also bright spots. The complex story is full of conspiracy, coverups and espionage. The numerous characters you'll encounter along the way are generally interesting and well-written, most of which have lengthy backstories that you might not be able to uncover in a single playthrough. It's the kind of quality work you'd expect from Obsidian.

And while the sneaking mechanics can be janky at times, going the stealth route is still a whole lot of fun. Executing non-lethal take-downs and maneuvering through levels quiety and undetected is a satisfying feeling. Focusing on stealth/pistol gameplay and playing the Sam Fisher role is the preferred way to go and helps improve the gameplay exponentially.

Given its flaws and inconsistencies, Alpha Protocol is (understandably) a game not everyone will enjoy. However, I feel that if you can look past its problems and appreciate the unique aspects of the game, you can really enjoy the product that Obsidian created. In my opinion it's one of the finer and most underrated RPGs of the last few years.

reviewText: First of all.. If you ever played Deus Ex and liked it, this is the game for you. If you didn't, you may very well still like it for a number of reasons.. If you like to sneak around, taking out enemies from behind with awesome takedowns or kills, this is the game for you. If you like a short, but actionfilled story that adapts to the way you play the game, this is the game for you. If you like charging in, guns blazin' and shooting everything with assault rifles, shotguns, SMGs or whatever, this is the game for you. This game has SO many options on how to play, act, etc., that a lot of people enjoys some aspect of it.\nPersonally I loved it, because everything you do, every choice you make, every answer you give, and every question you ask, have an impact on the storyline, which makes it a large web of events, tangling together, to create an epic feeling, forcing you to think on your feet, and actually pay attention to what happens around you, and the information you're given.
