reviewText: Way better than the negative reputation. The actual mission gameplay (Combat/stealth) is flawed, a bit too simplified so don't go expecting anything deep. The dialogue and plot repercussions system is -awesome-. Best comparison would be Mass Effect. If you're one of those people who complain when RPGs have too much text/chatter, skip it. For others it's a pretty great James Bond story. The possible plot branches and permutations are too many to count.

reviewText:
By far one of the jankiest and most enjoyable Action RPGs you can play.

Obsidian is nothing if not a writing savant and with Alpha Protocol it shines through. Gameplay is your basic spy game; stealth around, jump kick a guy, put several bullets in his head at once. Nothing groundbreaking but it doesn't need to be. As I said, it's packed to the brim with quality dialogue choices and trees that would make Mass Effect 3 weep. Shepard? Nah son, give me Steven Heck any day.

A+ quality Obsidian title. Don't expect some perfect simulation or deep immersion, you are looking at the wrong company for that.

reviewText:
A game world that reacts to what you do.

That's what a number of RPG-type gamers I've talked to want. They want their choices to make a difference to the plot. That's what Alpha Protocol is about. The things you do will be acknowledged. The way you do them will be noticed.

The combat system is easy to break, the game needed much more time in testing, and you really want a 360 controller for this. It is extremely buggy at times. But the underlying principle of this game is choice, and you get a lot of it.

Also there's a cocaine-fueled boss fight to the dulcent strains of Turn Up The Radio" by Autograph

reviewText:
Don't judge the game by the first hour.

This game is fantastically well-written. If you're a fan of RPGs and rate dialogue, story, characters and consequence over guns and explosions, you will absolutely love this game. I'm currently on my 3rd playthrough, and have had a very different experience each time. If the reason you loved Deus Ex: Human Revolution was because of the conspiracy, the dialogue challenges and the repurcussions of your actions then I would DEFINITELY recommend you play this.

Annoyingly, there is a definite learning curve and the movement and combat controls are lacking. I very nearly gave up on this game within the first hour, because I found the computer hacking minigame (coupled with the checkpoints save system) so frustrating I wasn't enjoying it at all. But I am VERY glad I stuck with it: once I got the hang of the hacking game and levelled my character to be more stealthy, the limitations became much less evident.

Buggy controls, but *superb* writing.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: The first original IP developed by Obsidian Entertainment, Alpha Protocol is an espionage role-playing game that follows Michael Thorton as he attempts to bring down Halbech Corporation, a military defense company. As Players travel to locations such as Rome, Moscow and Taipei, they uncover Halbech's true purpose for wanting Thorton dead. Highly Recommend.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Alpha Protocol is immediately underwhelming with unatmospheric graphics and a depressingly unoriginal opening (you wake up with amnesia and are talked through a training level) devoid of excitement, pacing, intrigue, spectacle or interest. Your dreary avatar humorously crouch-walks around the level giving you time to wonder why game designers have the bizarre belief that we bought a game about secret agents to be treated like an infant. We're supposed to be amazing; the game and characters should treat us as such in order to instil the relevant atmosphere. The problems with the game are legion; most notably, cover that frequently doesn't work, every boss fight being an exercise in gut-punching misery (despite one being brilliantly backed by Turn Up the Radio by Autograph) and being generally forced to choose a response before you hear enough of the lead-in. Additionally, the presence of sexual swear words feels wrong given the inspiration is clearly the bad-language-free JB spy gods o
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: This is one of those type of RPG's that is so misunderstood. I orginally played the game on 360 and enjoyed it so much I bought it on Steam as well. The thing people have to remember is that it plays like an RPG despite its 3rd person action perspective. This means that sniping sucks until you level sniping, and that you can become OP depending on which skills you choose to focus.\n\nBut with a story that has possibly more decisions to make than Mass Effect and with multiple endings, its an amazingly fun game as long as you play it as intended.

reviewText:
Alpha Protocol is what would happen if James Bond and cover shooters had a slightly autistic RPG baby.  It's game where everything works as advertised, and yet somehow doesn't..

If you love to run-and-gun, sneak your way through a level, or dispatch enemies with a wide variety of useful gadgets and tools then this is not really the game for you.  All these things are in the game, but only just enough to work, not enough to entertain.  The mechanics are largely broken with pistols being so powerful as to be game-breaking, and guns like the assault rifle so ♥♥♥♥♥♥ that it has trouble dispatching even the most basic of foes.  Gadgets are crap to worthless.

On the other hand if you love the idea of a storyline so malleable that almost any detail can be altered or changed, any character befriended or shot dead (even major NPCs, all the way down to changing the final boss) and shockingly engrossing, snappily written social sequences then Alpha Protocol will keep you playing again and again
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game got a seriously bad rap. It's not the best third-person shooter I've played, and oftentimes one might run into an annoying bug, but overall it's a game that offers a lot.

Espionage isn't the most investigated genre in the gaming industry, at least not to this level - and Obsidian did a good job of it. Globe-trotting, stealth missions, lethal or non-lethal methodologies - it's a good example of a good game being lambasted unfairly by the general public.

The dialogue and choice system are top-notch and can vastly change the playthrough from one game to the next. Most comparable to the dialogue system in Mass Effect, how you treat others can have serious ramifications long down the road; choices made when conversing with one character may completely alter the conversation you have with another several chapters later. A very impressive achievement, and one that seems to have flown under the radar of most.

Highly recommended.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Great story told in a nice game. Unfortunatelly, it's problematic to run it on some PCs. Must play" for any cRPG gamer."
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Awsome game, Recommended! Pity there isnt going to be a sequal to it :(
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
8.5 / 10 I think this game is totally under rated. the game must have been patched, i only saw one major glitch. the stealth in this game is pretty good, thats how i played it anyway, but it really only allows you to fully specialise in one weapon which is annoying.

Evasion allows you to go invistible for 3-6 seconds when an enemy sees you, to allow you to attack or hide. if stealth, you want the proper stealth gear ($130k) that is not avaible after you finish saudi arabia, get it there.

also there are other cool perks, hard to kill reserects you at death and allows you to recover. You have a secondary health that recharges, so it you hide somewhere, it gives you a good chance of survival.

SIUMMARISING, Its a subtle cross between hitman tactics and dues ex story line, but is not as good as either of those games. The amount of influence your decisions have on what happens next though, is very impressive. Would recommend. 22h to clock roughly
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: This game isn't perfect: it has its share of glitches, and just getting it to run can be quite the hassle.  It's worth the effort, though.  Besides the solid gameplay that allows you to pick virtually any approach with equal effectiveness, it shines head and shoulders above every other game in making your decisions meaningful.  Everything you say can have both large and small impacts on the future of the game, to the point that you can play it a dozen times and not see everything.  And that's no exaggeration - I've done it.  The game is that satisying.\n\nThe technical issues mean I can't give this game a strictly positive review, but if you can get past them, you'll find an incredibly solid and immersive game that will continue to surprise you even after several playthroughs.

reviewText:
A flawed gem. The AI is inconsistent, the controls are bad especially the godawful mouse controls, and it's very buggy. It has a rocky and boring start but quickly picks up after about 3-4 hours. The story is amazing and you're constantly forced to make morally grey decisions with consequences that actually have an effect on the plot.

If you're willing to look past or deal with the many issues it has, then you will find an experience that is rare to come by in modern gaming.

My full review:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GEG7F8dcuCs
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: One of the greatest RPGs I've had the fortune to play. The combat/stealth (Yes, a main selling point) leaves a lot to be desired, but as for the rest of the game, it couldn't be more spot on. It plays somewhat like Mass Effect, but I thought the story was much, much nicer, and the choices you make in this game actually impact the route that the rest of the game takes, instead of just giving you a different ending depending on X% of nice paths chosen vs X% of evil paths chosen.\n\nI'd say this game could go for $40-45. $60 would be a bit much, seeing as the combat/stealth portion is quite flawed, but I'd agree with up to $45. And guess what? It's only $15. You're getting an absolute steal here. (Note: I have multiple playthroughs of this, but for some reason time tracking didn't start until the end of my last playthrough. I probably have nearly 35-40 hours in it at the moment.)
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Playing Alpha Protocol is like trying to shave your ♥♥♥♥ with an electric razor because a woman once told you that your ♥♥♥♥♥♥ resembled an Ewok. But then if you compound that with the fact the razor is eight years old, has only one functioning speed (chainsaw), and feels about as smooth as a face rinse using a garbage disposal while munching on chewing gum made of glass and recycled kittens, you'd get the picture.\n\nPlaying Alpha Protocol is also like flying to Hobart for Easter only to find out when you get there that all of Tasmania is, in fact, now a black hole. But instead of vaporizing instantly into nothingness, you're forced to sit in an auditorium where the seats morph into goblins who munch off your balls and thrust javelins so far up your bum you choke on them. You’re forced to die slowly while watching reruns of Sex and the City on the JumboTron and wee elves drain your bank accounts by one-click-buying the world’s stock of Harry Potter merchandise on Amazon.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Excellent!
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
An excellent game that never got the recognition it deserved.

The plot, dialogue, setting and characters are all interesting and engaging; and the visuals are very good as well.
The combat and stealth systems do not have the level of depth you may expect from a modern 'pure' shooter or stealth game, but to me this is more than offset by the rpg elements and the flexibility of being able to approach pretty much every situation from a variety of different angles.  Your play experience depends a lot on what skills you level and what gear you buy; playing as a frontal-assault combat monster is very different from playing a more stealth or gadget-based character.
Almost everything you do has an impact on how the game unfolds; which missions you undertake at what time, how you treat characters, and how you deal with various situations, all change how things play out.

The only real negative I can think of, is that I've found that the controls can be a little jerky at some points when using a mouse.  However, this can be corrected by tweaking the mouse sensitivity or by using a game controller.

Alpha Protocol is a great game and a real treat for anyone interested in a character driven action rpg.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Alpha Protocol was largely overshadowed by the release of Mass Effect 2 when it first came out, meaning a lot of people missed out on this actually really good game.  It's not the best game you'll ever play, but it is still pretty great.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Great game but it could have been so much more.

Good:
It's a spy shooter that let's you play the way you want, stealth, guns blazing, etc.  An RPG skill system can be used to bolster your play style, for example developing lock pickking, silent running, rifles, explosives, etc. Your choices in and out of combat give you influence with various characters and ultimately decide how the story unfolds and how the game ends.

Bad:
It was obviously dumbed down for consoles.
Some of the hacking mini games are annoying
Although the story is good, some of the choices are forced a la Mass Effect, choose who dies.
Worse, it does so, by commiting the ultimate gameplay sin where you win a battle, but lose in a cutscene.

Overall.  I love the game, but it could have been so much better.  As with many Obsidian games, the final execution just isn't quite there.  When will game makers understand that the real art isn't forcing us to choose who dies.  It's in allowing us to discover how to save both, or maybe not to be the hero and let them all die.  Still, highly worth playing.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Perfect example of game with good ideas and poor execution, you will love the dialogs and the choice and consequence, on the other the presentation and overall feeling as an action game (it's better if you play it the stealth way) is poor.\n\nStill, at the end of the day, it at least tried to be a unique experience; and with a fair amount of patience, you will enjoy the game.

reviewText: I must buck the trend and say I adored this game. I finished it three times doing every conceivable option and character build. The faction system forged through real character choices is fantastic. The dialogue system keeps things interesting as well. Likewise, I actually loved the combat system, although the game was too easy. Also, AP has perfect pacing; levels never drag on and the game keeps you interested until the end. I only experienced a few minor bugs, so I really can't relate to all these complaints. To me AP will go down as one of the most under-appreciated games ever. To each his or her own, but if you can look past the hate and ignore the quirks, you too might just become obsessed with being Michael Thorton.

reviewText:
+Great Varied Gameplay (stealth/action/conversation)
+Fun TPS RPG
+Mission Variety
+Good, but not memorable voice acting and characters

-Graphics are okay, most glaring graphical hitches are enemy walking animations
-Context based movement (climbing ladders, jumping ledges, drops)
-Limited Weapon Variety

This game compares very favorably to a mix of Deus Ex Human Revolution (ability acquisition), Mass Effect 2 (conversation options / TPS cover combat), and Uncharted (TPS cover combat / Characters / Stealth Takedown Animations).  I like this game better than Mass Effect 2 in terms of actual gameplay in both conversation options and combat.  However, its story is not unique enough to awe you like Mass Effect.  The whole time though, I kept on thinking to myself that if they put a little more polish in the graphics and made the movement free" instead of contextual like Uncharted or the Assassin's Creed games

reviewText: The first thing you will notice is that the combat itself is very.... unique. When I first played AP, it was hard to get into but I persisted, hearing good things about this game from other people. After the first few mission were over and the international plot began to emerge, along with the characters who would be along for the ride with you, I was hooked. It is an RPG, not a shooter by any stretch. And what an RPG. Obsidian continue to impress with the story lines. No binary good/bad system is in the game, something which shows this game to be beyond anything before. Many will think of Mass Effect while playing, and to an extent they are right. The first ME was a poor combat game but a good RPG. This is a brilliant RPG: each choice makes a diffrence, every single dialogue choice could change the end of the game in subtle ways.\n\nThis game could be much better. The combat and stealth could work in a more logical way, the pistol could stop been the answer to EVERY combat question. But the dialogue, plot and characters make this all worth playing.

reviewText: Based on the three J.B.s: Jason Bourne, Jack Bauer and James Bond this is a spy game where you choose the action, stealth or suave demeanor to get though. Despite the less and glowing reviews this game is worth the time you spend with it. Fun missions, decent storyline, and a chance to live off the radar. If you want something different from your FPS that has some RPG elements, and some nifty dialog choices, then give it a try. One last thought not sure why so many reviewers had technical difficulties with the game, but none were found during my play though, possibly the patches have done their job. Overall a Good game.

reviewText:
This game is fantastic! For 2 dollars your can't argue to NOT buy this game, a lot bad rep kept this game from shining. No one ever gave the game a chance, it is fantastic, with well impleted RPG system, making a mix, with metal gear(cover system) and character development(Fallout).

Tip: By going out your class, I mean if you are building a stealth character don't expect him to be good at frontal combat, your gonna suck. This IS an rpg, so you can't  go gun toting ala Gears, COD. The enemies will bring you down, for playing stupid, so play with brains & not ♥♥♥♥♥ mode. In one word GET IT.

reviewText: This is almost the definition of a 'flawed gem' game, with some fantastic ideas showcased throughout its' 15-20 hour runtime, some of which are implemented better than others. While the gameplay can feel rough around the edges at times (and stealth gets a bit too easy upon attaining what is, essentially, a 'temporary invisibility' perk), the story and characters are this game's highlight in my opinion, with good dialogue and great character development (particularly via their interactions with the player character). Also, the amount of choice given to the player adds a couple of playthroughs' worth of replayability. Its' fairly linear level structure may not appeal to some though, so be mindful of this before purchase if this is a game-breaker for you.\n\nOverall, although the game has a lot of bugs and some shortcomings, this is a game I readily recommend to RPG fans, especially those looking for a modern setting and an engaging story.

reviewText: Yes, this game has some fundamental flaws and could have used some more testing before it was released.  BUT, if you enjoy the decision elements of western RPG's such as Mass Effect, and open-ended gameplay like Deus Ex, you will love the twists and turns available to you in Alpha Protocol.  I have played through this game twice, taking two very different approaches, and it was almost literally like playing two entirely different games.  My suggestion for making the most of this game: build your character to be stealthy (the stealth system was well-refined) and throw any obsession you have about choosing the correct" conversation option out the window: you will ALWAYS be rewarded for whatever option you take
date: even if what you chose seems ridiculous!"

reviewText: Overall pretty decent game. Stealth mechanics leave a little to be desired. Fairly limited movement (jumping, dropping) is only available at certain spots. reviewText:
This game is great in some ways and completely broken in others.  The story is fun.  James Bond the RPG in a nutshell.  Nothing wrong with the premise.  Interesting characters and locations.  Stealth mechanics are ok and the dialog options is some of the best in any game and thats including dialog wheels in Bioware games.  Its Obsidian so good dialog is what you can expect.

It falls apart when you actually have to do combat.  Gunplay is iffy at best and while melee is fine you rarely get a chance to do it without running across a room to do it and thats rediculous.  The part that truly brings this game down is the bosses.  OMG the worst bosses in any game ever.  Hell I would argue this game didn't need bosses.  Its a game about being a spy gaining intel and learning who the bad guy is.  Forced boss fights with normal people who take a gazillion shots is bad enough but they are insanely hard for no reason.  90% of the boss fights I died like 10 times before I was able to beat them and i feel it was mostly luck that did it for me.  I regret putting this game on normal because it was damn near impossible.  In fact the first time I tried the game it was impossible.  One boss fight was simply unbeatable from how I leveled Michael and that is just stupid!  Level up right or you will never finish the game.  Put points into stealth to make every mission easy and max out pistol because the pistol becomes your best friend.  Put in a lot of points to a second gun as well.  Assault Rifle served me well.   This is not advice this is required to actually get through the game.  Without stealth most missions will drive you nuts with the combat.  Without pistols at high level bosses will destroy you.  Even then put the game on easy.

I had fun with this game but I also got angry with it too often to count.  I just wish I put it on easy because there's nothing to prove in giving yourself an anuerysm for those damn boss fights.

reviewText:
Let me just start by saying the Alpha Protocol is one of the few RPGs I know that have delivered on it's 'choice changes the game' mechanic. I've played this game for 80 hours now, and I can say that there's cutscenes I have seen in LPs that I haven't even played before.

GameplayHonestly, this isn't the best combat I've ever seen. You can play with stealth, or just shoot everything in the face. You start off with 4 classes to choose from which have perk points already in some predetermined places, but you can mix them up. A 5th option, Recruit, has you starting with no perk points at all, making the game a lot harder. Completing the Recruit option will unlock Veteran for future playthroughs, who has perks from previous experience.
You can carry two weapons with you at a time, ranging from an assault rifle, a shotgun, an smg and a pistol. They can be upgraded and you can even buy more of them in the safehouse.
The safehouse serves as a hub for you inbetween missions, allowing you to read your emails (which sometimes contain funding or other useful information), watch TV about 'recent affairs', or check the black market. On the black market you can buy things ranging from a map of the complex to intelligence on a person.
You can build up intel on people or groups, and knowing it can sometimes give you an extra option in conversations. They also give you a certain damage bonus against some of the bosses.

StorySPOILERS:
The story begins with you, Mike Thorton, waking up in a secret government facility. You break out, only to find that it was a test of your abilities. You are sent off to Saudi Arabia, to recover stolen Halbech missiles. A terrorist group has stolen them, and they used them to blow up a civillian plane earlier. There will be sequences where you are sat in a room talking to a man about what you have just done. The idea is that the missions happened months ago, and you're being interrogated now. You will learn in Saudi that the missiles were never stolen, they were given freely by Halbech. With the help of an agent, Mina, who is still operating in the AP facility, you escape, and quickly realise that Halbech are attempting to spark a war, so that they can ramp up production and earn more money. Off the data you take with you you find that there are three major Halbech locations. They are Rome, Taipei and Moscow. You can visit them in any order, but the game will change considerably based on which one you go to. After collecting information on Halbech, you have to return to the AP base to finish it all. Based on if you romanced anyone or you were good friends with them and they survived, they will join you on a final boatride into the sunset.

VerdictThe story is extremely well written and has a very high replayability, only being dragged down by the combat. For that, I'll give it an 7/10

reviewText: Alpha Protocol is a spy themed action RPG in which you play as Michael Thorton. A guy recently signed onto a super secret ultraviolet level covert ops group that do jobs that other organizations can't handle. Plays like a third person shooter like Mass Effect 2, with your standard cover mechanics and dialog choices. With the dialog you can choose to play your character like different spy archetypes ranging from Sean Connery James Bond to straight up 'WHERE'S THE BOMB!?' Jack Bauer. However some skill trees are broken and one part of a game takes a cocaine fueled difficulty spike.\n\nFun game overall, rack up orphans and hospital bills over your spy career.

reviewText: On one hand, it's a clunky, slippery, buggy and unpolished game. On the other hand, it's a pretty unique Action-RPG hybrid with a flexible role-playing system, engaging branching storyline with morally ambiguous choices to make, and a lot of replay options through both action and dialog via the cause and effect system. I'd still say give Alpha Protocol a try, especially whenever it's on sale.

Put points into stealth to make every mission easy and max out pistol because the pistol becomes your best friend.  Put in a lot of points to a second gun as well.  Assault Rifle served me well.   This is not advice this is required to actually get through the game.  Without stealth most missions will drive you nuts with the combat.  Without pistols at high level bosses will destroy you.  Even then put the game on easy.

I had fun with this game but I also got angry with it too often to count.  I just wish I put it on easy because there's nothing to prove in giving yourself an anuerysm for those damn boss fights.

reviewText:
It was a very nice surprise. It is not a perfect game though. Boring and hard-to-figure-out in the beggining, but nicely developed thoughout the story.

The game is divided into chapter, which one comprises of a series of missions to investigate an international security issue. Well done. The safehouse concept was very well implemented in which you can buy/sell weapons, gadgets, and key intel to unlock additional side missions (investigations) related to chapter's story mission.

After completing the first chapter, you can choose from 5 professional styles which of them with unique abilities and gadgets. I can relate spy, soldier, engineer, etc.  I chose spy...it is a stealth game, guys. But fell free to choose a different one to go assaulting everywhere. Also, there are a wide variety of weapons to fit with your choosen professional style. That would allow game replayability. As you progress you gather experience points that will lead to characther's level up and upgrade points to allow you improving certain abilities at your choice.

Level design are very nice. Again, this game have its isues, but it gathers the best elements of stealth action games: Hitman, Splinter Cell, Batman, Deus EX, you can recall other games in every element of this game as you play it. It is not purely linear, because by using the safehouses, you can return to certain areas to collect items, hacking computers, find money caches, collect ammo, etc. THAT IS GREAT.

As a RPG, dialog system is a bit different from other similar games. Here, you may choose your reply tone rather than the response phrase itself. Options varies from sarcastic, professional, ironic, flirtatious...Oh yes, there are romance options you can decide about. You also can reply to emails to disclose sensitive information, flirt, threat and compliment someone else in your mailing list. Here your decisions matter and will affect the game ending.

Weapon wheel are difficult to browse at the beggning but I got used to. There are lethal and non lethal takedowns that are cool.  It resembles the Krav Maga martial art. Mini games are not that cool, some of them are tough, but you can buy certain upgrades to help you out. There are abilities you can upgrade with its cooldown time that can be reduced with level up points.

The weakiest part were the Boss battles that should be much better. Without spoilling, there are certain upgrades and gadgets that will make your life way too easy fighting bosses. But overall, it is enjoayble and worth playing.  It is worth playing with moderate expectations.

RECOMMENDED.

reviewText:
It’s third person shooter/RPG that is most similar to Deus Ex: Human Revolution and Mass Effect. The plot is very reminiscent of James Bond and other rouge spy movies.

The story is actually pretty intriguing and decently written, involving different factions of spies, mercenaries, terrorists and secret police; taking you to places such as Moscow, Rome and Taipei.  Its interaction mechanics with NPCs during cut-scenes is the highlight of this game.  It allows you to chose different dialog choices that influences the story and character relationships. The cast of characters is colorful and they are all very interesting. Each NPC has a unique and different personality and a huge part/theme of the game is manipulating people to get what you want, that means acting aggressive, professional or suave depending on the person. Your relationships and interactions can also influence the way a mission plays out, whether or not you’ll receive back up, determining who are going to be fighting, and what items on the black market you can purchase. The game also emphasizes dossiers and gathering intel, which gives passive combat bonuses to specific factions and helps you learn about a character’s background so that you can learn how you’re supposed to talk to them if you want them to like you. Missions offer multiple paths, approaches and options. You can also bang MOST of the chicks in one play through, if you play your cards right (this is, hands down, the best part).

Combat and controls can feel clunky, it seems like they wanted to make weapon specialization and stats like accuracy, stability and recoil matter in a third person shooter, so it forces you to ‘focus’ your cross hair on your target before you can shoot or else your shots will be all over the place.  This can make early game very annoying because your shots won’t focus fast enough, and any kind of long ranged combat becomes a pain.  The game forces boss fights, there is no stealth solution, you have to straight up fight them so it's highly reccomended that you pump up the stats in at least one weapon (fun fact pistol is over power). Regardless of the boss fights, playing stealth is generally over power, it rewards you with more stuff than a straight up commando/aggressive play, and it trivializes a lot of missions. There are 2 hacking mini-games, a word search and clicking tangled wires in a specific order. They get repetitive fast and are not really fun. The game can also be glitchy at times; there have been times when I’ve been spotted and never should have been (through a wall), times where I’ve gotten stuck in walls and had to die or reload my save, and the game had crashed on me 4 times throughout my play through.

I’d recommend it if you like the talking parts of the Dues Ex and Mass Effect or just enjoy a good story driven game. You’d have to deal with the par combat, missions and maybe a rough early game.

reviewText: This game is proof that Metacritic is a broken for review measurements. 72/100 these days conjures up ideas of mediocrity and most people would have lowered expectations. However, this game is anything but mediocre. Some dodgy AI aside (such as enemies not seeing you when you are stood right next to them) this game is brilliant; great locations, great story and choices that feel that they matter. reviewText:
Perhaps unpolished, but still a gem.
Fan of Deus Ex, or Vampire the Masquerade: Bloodlines, and their brethren of immersive sims?  Don't pass up Alpha Protocol.

Be warned, of course.  The game is riddled with severe technical problems; across two PCs and two operating systems, this game has proven more challenging to merely run than any other game I've played in the last five years.

However, it is also among the very best.  The setting is lacking any particularly fantastical elements, and the characters are arguably not especially memorable, but the intrigue is well presented, and subtly woven.

The game's dialogue system is superb, reminiscent of Mass Effect, but with the addition of a timer, forcing you to make decisions on the spot and stick by them.  Characters react to your playstyle, and the choice to play stealthily, non-lethally, or  loudly and violently will ultimately impact certain sequences.  Don't expect to notice massive consequences for your choices, but repeated playthroughs show an excptional number of subtle, appreciated differences.

Gameplay is ambitiously diverse.  Certainly, as a whole, it controls somewhat awkwardly, as the game does not master any of its elements entirely, but it offers many options competently enough.  The standard paths are available; stealth, hacking, gunplay, and melee (unarmed, in this case) are all present.  Various abilities, unlocked through RPG-like progression, offer a feeling of meaningful specialization, and nicely allow you to focus on a certain skillset.

If you can tolerate its technical failings, Alpha Protocol offers an experience that's difficult to compare to any other recent releases.  It was clearly a labor of love, and fans of other Obsidian games probably know what to expect, in terms of its stability.

Highly recommended, if you want to take a risk on something different from the norm.

reviewText:
Alpha Protocol is a flawed, but enjoyable gem the likes that Obisidan tends to provide. Playing somewhat similar to Mass Effect, with heavier consequences that are not only more dramatic but also further down the storyline, Alpha Protocol provides an excellent game surrounded by the nuances of Espionage.

Visually, it is interesting but with it's flaws. Animations are rigid and lack the smooth transitions that many other games have. Gameplay in itself can feel a bit awkward with controls and it may take a bit of time to get used to the way weapons interact with a Roleplaying interface.

With no sequel, grab this if you enjoy spy games with a heavy emphasis on relationships with your co-workers, targets, and other people as well as prefer a stronger Roleplaying aspect to the likes of Mass Effect.

I'd give this game 7.5/10. Buy it if you see it on SALE.

reviewText:
I love this game. Don't let any of those trolls get you down on the negative aspects because if you are a fan of any spy in the history of literature then you will love this. This made me watch Bond, Mission Impossible, 24 and Taken again just for reference. The first playthrough I wanted to get a feel for it so I went with the Mission Impossible route, some jokes, some professionalism, making friends with poeple you come accross for info. Then I played full bond, just a pistol, no armor, stealth, suave and of course if you are a Roger Moore fan, the corny and suggestive jokes. Then I played as Jack Bauer, agressive, confrontational, but knows when to kill and not to kill. Then I played full on Taken and opened up a can of Liam Neeson on my enemies which turned it into less of a spy movie and more into a Rambo like movie where anyone who got in my way or was a potential threat....they were dealt with. So if you are a big fan of either one here is the playstyle to follow.

Ethan Hunt: Mixuture of everything including armor and weapons, little to no suave but plenty of jokes and yet maintain seriousness and mostly stealth

007: You can be as aggressive as Brosnan and Craig or as snarky and funny as Moore, to the cockyness of Connery and if you feel the need to throw in some Dalton gun play go for it. However everyone besides Dalton does not wear any kind of armor so be warned.

Jack Bauer: Again little to no armor but damn aggressive and up front, you basically carves through anyone he wishes yet spares those he has has to. This would be the hard gameplay.

Liam Neeson: This would be the INSANE game style, no armor, just a pistol, wits and of course you eliminate EVERYONE and I mean EVERYONE. Which makes everyone mad but hey its Neeson we are talking about here.

Then you have others:

The strong quiet types like Steven Seagal to Rambo and the Commando Arnold (which is a specialization option)

So which ever spy you want to emulate go for it. I prefer Bond and word to the wise, download a track or two from the movies, really sets the RPG mood.

reviewText:
Obsidian is one of the few developers who have earned my trust enough for me to be willing to buy their games without hesitating. I can't think of a game by them that ever disappointed me, but I can think of plenty that became some of my favorites, and Alpha Protocol is one of them.

In terms of the core gameplay, the game is only slightly above average. It's framed as a stealth game, but there are plenty of character options to let you play as loud or quiet as you want, or even dump all your points into Martial Arts and become a kung fu spy if you want. The AI can be a bit finnicky sometimes, and the camera mouse controls sometimes have issues, but for the most part it's functional, and fun to play. The real distinguishing factor of the game is in the dialogue, and other choices. An average playthrough may only last 10 to 15 hours or so, but it has enough replayability to easily make it worth playing several times. Everything from the order you take on missions in to the people you ally with likely has an effect on future events, and there are enough ways that events can play out differently to continue to surprise you even after 3 or 4 playthroughs. The game features a full Bond-like cast of memorable characters, each of whom have their own likes and dislikes that can influence your results throughout the game. It really puts up the illusion that this is a real world of espionage, and it's easy to find yourself invested in the character and story because of it.

The one place where the game does falter is the dialogue interface itself. The game uses a Mass Effect-style one-word-choice system, where most dialogue choices fall into three categories - Suave, Aggressive, and Professional. It's not as simplistic as it may seem, and it is somewhat necessary to shorten the lines since unlike other similar games Alpha Protocol is fairly aggressive with its timed dialogues and often may not even give you more time than it takes for a character to finish their sentence to make a decision, but it does occasionally end with you misreading the prompt's intention and leading to the main character saying something you didn't want. This ties in with the fact that the main character's voice actor isn't all that great at times, and he doesn't do a very good job of actually sounding particularly suave when you pick those options. Alpha Protocol is the one game where I don't completely hate the use of the dialogue wheel, but I still wouldn't mind it being gone.

If you're into Bond movies or just spy fiction in general, Alpha Protocol is a pretty easy pick. Almost every Obsidian game has their faults due to both publishers rushing them and Obsidian themselves not being that great at managing their time, but like most of their games the faults aren't enough to bring down what ends up being another really great RPG to add to their list.

reviewText: So far, this game is very interestings combining an action/spy game with RPG elements. Now so far it is executed very well, stong graphics, great sound, fluid gameplay..AI is a little off at times and I can see this game becoming very difficult as you progress further. The small puzzles are great such as the Lockpicking, computer hacking and alarm disabling are nothing ground breaking but add to the the game. Being able to customize your player skills is fantastic and really shine as it hits right on the mark to add the rpg feel to the game. I would recommend this game for anyone who enjoys James Bond or Mission impossible style gameplay, with Martial arts, cover and many more features. This game seems to combine a little of everything which might be its downfall of trying to do to much but so far makes for a fantastic game! i would recommend while its on sale to pick it up!

reviewText:
The writing in this espionage RPG is top notch and this is one game where your choices really do matter. This makes it quite repayable.  That being said, everything else is a bit of a clunky mess.

I recommend Alpha Protocol for its first rate storytelling, but advise you to wait till it's on sale for $5 or so.

reviewText: Every aspect of gameplay is awful: glitchy controls, poor AI, you name it and its broken. Dialogue is riddled with quicktime events, and thanks to the awful controls you will never get the choice you want. To make matters worse, the autosave system is set up to prevent you from reloading when you get shafted by the broken controls. This game is so bad I wouldn't recommend it even if they gave it away free.

reviewText:
8.5/10

+ nice presentation overall, good character models, some bad textures though, could use more detail in the environment, the art is fine though
+ gameplay is very interesting overall, with great variety, from stealth to fps, with some high tech tools depending on how you choose to play it
+ excellent writing, some fantastic dialogues, very deep dialogue tree, as you expect from one of the companies that have mastered it (obsidian)
+ conspiracy story, a bit generic , but it is presented in a realistic way, some very nice side missions that you get to choose as well
+ good upgrade system, weapons variety etc

- rough technically, mediore animations, generic fps mechanics, generic melee mechanics, fighting certainly needed a polish
- could last longer (especially if you go all the way to the main story without caring for the side missions it is really short)
- nothing else, it could be a masterpiece if they gave more time to its production, highly recommended though especially to those bored of all the fantasy rpg games out there

reviewText:
Alpha Protocol is the quintessential flawed gem: many faults, a lot of heart and lack of execution. I enjoyed this game a lot no matter all the design's faults. The story is great in terms of reactivity and  roleplaying but sadly the story alone cannot save the game from all its problems and most importantly  for the lack of a coherent overall vision (that can be explained with the troubled story of its development).

H(o)rgasm Rating (Holistic Review Gameplay Art Story Metrics):

Gameplay: 12/25 (mediocre)
Art: 15/25 (good)
Story: 23/25 (great)
Holistic Rating: 10/25 (the execution and the lack of vision kills the positive parts of the experience)

Total Rating: 60... but the rating do not says it all in this case! It's noth high because I try to be as objective as I can but I still recommend this game to all the RP genre's lovers.

reviewText:
One of the most under rated games!

Pros:
* It's a fantastic RPG experience: good mix between action, stealth and RPG.
* The storyline and characters are awesome.
* All your decisions (kill civilians, leave a boss alive, etc.) have real consequence.
* Like any RPG, you have to choose your skill, buy/sell weapons, objects, ammo, etc.
* You can play each mission like Rambo, or Sam Fischer or a mix of them (kill only enemies).
* Good replayability (Kill Them All, save the civilians, flirt with all the girls, etc.)

Cons:
* Some lag if you move your mouse too quickly
* Sega have abandoned the series

Buy it, buy it now :p
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
First I thought, oh hey, a bargain for 2 Euros.

Then I started the game... and suddenly lost 6 hours of my life before I realized that it is well past midnight.

This game is pure awesome. It delivers on presentation, story, sound only sometimes I wish I could fiddle with the mouse sensitivity for sniping. The effects of your in-game decisions are very visible in the storyline and so far, it looks as if there is no right or wrong choice... you just play like you want to play. If I had to, I would describe this game like a playable version of a James Bond movie who had a love child with the Burn Notice TV series.

As long as it is 90% off, BUY IT! No excuses! This game is well worth the money and I would pay 40 bucks and consider it money well spent. The last time I had so much fun was with Mass Effect 1 and 2.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Alpha protocol's story is possibly one of the best I've seen when it comes to spy games/movies.It's complex,but not confusing, rewarding multiple playthroughs.The dialogue also comes through,as it's well written and it's mass effect-esque dialogue branch keeps multiple playthroughs fresh.Unfortunatelly,it also has the same problem as Mass Effect,as some of the dialogue choices you make might actually mislead you and have unintended results(like negatively affecting your stance with a character).
As usual in an Obsidian game,it also suffers from technical problems,raging from slowdowns on certain machines to enemies not loading on a quick-load.The gameplay also suffers from slight imbalances,with some bossfights being resistant to weapons/skills you might have selected.

If it's going for cheap,do get the game.The story alone is worth it!

Note:DRM was removed on patch 1.1 so you don't need to worry about install limits anymore.

reviewText: Alpha Protocol has one of the best interactive conversation-driven story devices I've played in a long time. How do you not own alpha protocol? This is a fantastic game, you actually owe it to yourself to give it a shot. Just remember, it' doesn't play like an FPS, it's a stat/numbers based shooter in playstyle (i.e. shots only hit if your stat numbers are high enough, where you aim the cursor doesn't matter worth a damn - it's not Gears of War).

reviewText: Alpha Protocol is a bipolar title. If strictly estimated on the gameplay, you can not overlook the serious problems of balance in terms of character development (there are combinations that literally break the game in the later stages), while the stealth sessions and the AI ​​deficit are to be reviewed completely. However, assessed on the RPG side, the game is surprising for the vastness of the choices allowed, not only with regard to the growth of our pg and for the approach to missions, but it will also be possible to completely change the outcome of the events and characters, so that every game will never be the same as another.\nThe dialogue system is as it should be in the last Bioware titles, especially if you wanted to bet on cinematograficity: there is a wheel, not the phrases severed but with the attitude to be taken, which obviously work differently depending dell'interlocutor, plus the ability to gather information to exploit. Everything is in time, a solution that, if at the beginning can be confusing, serves well to remain vigilant of the player and the pace of the narrative.\nDefinitely recommended to all lovers of spy stories, as long as you close an eye on the technical side.

What a great game ! It' an underrated gem , The stealth mechanics are not revolutionary or mind blowing but they'll alright , The character interactions are where the game shines though .. anything you say can change a character's attitude , actions , or feelings towards you , and yes it all matters unlike most RPGs , If you were honest with a certain character they'll actually appreciate it later on , and if your playstyle is stealthy then some characters will joke about how sneaky you are and so on..

reviewText:
I tried to like this game, I really did. After hearing absolutely damning reviews, I wonderd if this was going to be one of those 'Deadly Preminition' type games where the awsomeness and hilarity of the story makes up for it's abominable gameplay. Unfornately I was dissapointed.

Enemies see you from 100 meters away in stealth. Even if you're behind something. Line of sight is completely broken.
The guns feel like pea shooters and the combat system is flat out not there with basically one button to mash until you know the dude out.

Movement is awkward and strange as the Protaganist seemingly proceeds to slide and float across the ground and the myriad  of glitches where I fell through the floor and got stuck.

The story I never got to experience properly as I never got off the first level where I had to hack a door. The minigames are also mindbengingly annoying as it seems that it was designed for a controller.

Dont bother with this. Unless you're getting this with the Humble Bundle, then I cant think of a reason for anybody to play this.

reviewText:
This game frequently gets compared to the famous Mass Effect Series. To be honest though, all the two have in common are the graphic engine, the 3rd person view and the fact, that you as a player get to choose the direction of your ingame conversations. Still, the comparison can be made in order to help people decide, if this game might be for them, or not.

While Mass Effect is a lot more RPG (especially the first game) as it lets you wander around, talk to npcs and aquire quests, Alpha Protocol is a bit more linear in its storytelling, since only the order in which you complete your missions and the order of your missionhubs can be determined by the player.

The missions itself are pretty action-oriented, even though you might want to take a stealthy approach from time to time in order to take out a few enemies without being noticed or to move into a more favorable position for your assault. It is possible to put lots of talent points into being 'stealthy' and playing almost exclusively like this, but it has to be said that the game is by no means a Splinter Cell and some direct confrontation especially during the last stages of the game is unavoidable.

Mission locations are quite diversified, while the level design itself is very linear. During your missions you'll receive radio support by your 'handler', who updates you with the latest mission relevant information. In addition, you'll frequently encounter locked doors and password protected computers, which you'll be able to open or hack by beating one of the increasingly difficult mini-games.

The graphics are decent, I especially liked the facial textures of the characters and the depth of field effects. The voice-acting is great, the writing is excellent, as it often offers you funny witty responses in dialogues and also features your expected conspiracy theories and the like.

Another note on the subject of dialogue choices in this game: unlike Mass Effect, where you get to choose the exact response you want to give and have unlimited time in deciding on which one it is going to be, you can only choose the general tone and direction of your answer in Alpha Protocol, while at the same time being forced to make this decision within a few seconds. Responses include 'professional', 'threatening', 'suave', 'flirtatious' or a certain subject you want to touch upon. While initially this system felt irritating, once you get used to it, it feels rather dynamic and natural, since there are no pauses during dialogues and you are forced to make decisions on the fly.

Decisions in this game have a real impact on the main plot aswell, as often you'll have to make meaningful choices between making allies or enemies, life and death or something of similar weight. Characters react differently to your approach during conversations, and since the game keeps track of your standing with each character, I often find myself reading up on a character's personal files before talking to them in order to get a better understanding of what said npc might react most positively to.

So what can you expect from this game? Solid, but not spectacular 3rd person shooter gameplay in a spy setting with some stealth elemtents and gadgets, engaging cutscenes and conversations with meaningful decisionmaking wrapped in a rather complex storyline.

Less depth than Mass Effect, less playtime and less production value - but by no means a bad game. The only thing the game really lacks because of this are the big, breathtaking moments. Nonetheless, Alpha Protocol has some pretty memorable scenes (including hook-ups, you perv!) and I am quite satisfied with my first playthrough.

Especially if you like the spy-setting, want something tight and less drawn out and prefer a more action-oriented approach to the genre, Alpha Protocol is a must-have.
voteText: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Alpha Protocol is significantly fiddly, partially unfinished, occasionally broken, and utterly ridiculous, but it is also a pretty good time.  If you can manage not to take it too seriously and are willing to cheap your way through sticky situations, you will enjoy this ambitiously nonlinear and surprisingly memorable spy-genre action-RPG.
voteText: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
When I got the game from a bundle, I was not expecting much from it and thought it would be a medicore game. Oh god, I was so wrong and I ain't even complaining about it. AP is a TPS-RPG hybrid like Mass Effect series but unlike ME it takes place in today's world. It leaves us to take control of a spy and go on missions all across the world. If I told anything about the story I'd probably spoil something unintentionall so I'll just leave pros and cons

Pros:
-Dialogue system is pretty nice and gives you a few seconds to make your choice, makes it more realistic IMO
-The game lets you decide entirely how you're gonna play it. You can be a stealth assassin and catch people unaware, go Rambo against an army, run to people and punch them to death etc etc
-Weapon/armor variety and upgrades are nice and enables you to custimize your weapons/armor to suit your playstyle
-Can be finished multiple times to see all parts of story(long playability time)
-Great story filled with betrayals, treasons, revenge, love and lots of interesting stuff
-Things like lockpicking and bypassing stays enjoyable through your playthtrough
-Watching the news and hearing whatever you've done on the broadcast is a fun detail, and also everything you do on a mission effects the(close or far) future ones

Cons:
-Hacking. Honestly it is so stressing and tiring that I found myself wishing it didn't exist. It was fun in the first 2-3 time but having it as the most frequent minigame and making it harder and harder just killed the magic.
-Camera can be a bit messy sometimes.
-Some people say they encountered many bugs on internet but throughout my playththrough I only faced literally 2 bugs
-Sometimes guns require too much accuracy(stat). Eventhough you point your gun to the other person's head and wait for it to be in critical state it may not even leave a scratch on them
-AI can screw hard during combats
-Skills make the game too easy(trying to play it without skills is fun though but challanging)

That's all I can say, I guess. I think this game is criminally underrated and even though I got it from a bundle, I'd happily pay the original price to play it.

P.S: I reccomend playing the game as stealth assassin as it is more fun and AI is much better during the stealth times
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
I consider Alpha Protocol a guilty pleasure. Sure the gameplay isn't particularly great, and if you're not careful when you level up you can make some decisions with your character that make the rest of the game rather difficult, but all the drawbacks fall to the wayside when you get to the story and the character interactions.

This game builds on the Bioware approach to storytelling and character development. Your choices aren't clearly Good/Bad/Funny/Jerk/Farewell. The choices you make will affect the storyline rather decently and sometimes you just won't get the full picture of the plot unless you go through it multiple times.

reviewText:
I consider Alpha Protocol a guilty pleasure. Sure the gameplay isn't particularly great, and if you're not careful when you level up you can make some decisions with your character that make the rest of the game rather difficult, but all the drawbacks fall to the wayside when you get to the story and the character interactions.

This game builds on the Bioware approach to storytelling and character development. Your choices aren't clearly Good/Bad/Funny/Jerk/Farewell. The choices you make will affect the storyline rather decently and sometimes you just won't get the full picture of the plot unless you go through it multiple times.

reviewText: This game was in my opinion missed due to all the great RPGs that came out last year. Despite it's FPS interface, it is an RPG similar in style to Mass Effect. Unlike other RPGs and Stealth FPS games, the action doesn't stop when the conversations start. Conversations are battles themselves because you are given only a short time to decide how to respond and your repsonses make a difference from mission to mission, not just the end game.

reviewText: Terrific game.  Not sure how I didn't catch it when it first came out.  Good combat, meaningful RPG choices, fun character progression and a tight story with upper eschelon voice acting.  This, alongside the Deux Ex series makes me want a whole lot more of this type of non-D&D-style RPG.\n\nSadly Sega owns Alpha Protocol as Obsidian only developed it.  Sega's a horrible publisher that only seems interested in making content-less games that they backfill via DLC for $150 (TW, DoW, CoH).  It's hard to offer a content-less story-driven, action RPG.  I hope we see a trilogy but I don't have high hopes.

reviewText:
After have just finished this game on hard as a recruit/spy I am just glad to be done with the game.
Sure it has the positive part where all your decisions affects your missions and such.
The controls are really annoying sometimes when you wanna get out of cover or how you wanna throw grenades at times.
Enemies can sometimes shoot through cover and kill you that way. Yes, certain things are breakable and that is fine but when getting shot through walls and behind cover is annoying and frustrating.
Some boss fights are very hard. All depends on how you build your character but without certain ones it makes it almost insanely hard. Picking some skills makes it way easy to get through the game.
I was hoping for more stealth and sneak but sometimes that was no option at all.
The dialogs sometimes made me cringe so badly I almost wanted to mute it. There is one allied I liked in the game and he is craaaazy but funny. Made it somewhat fun at least.
Graphics and sound were fine for the type of game it is.
I can't recommend this game on my experience of the game thou.

reviewText:
Not recommendedEven though I thought this game sounded quite promising, and I really wanted to like it, I don't. It seems as if there was a lot of potential regarding what they wanted to do, but I don't think it was done well.

Graphics
Yes, the game is from 2010, so keep that in mind. However, I think that, even for 2010, the graphics aren't that good. Character editing (glasses, hat, hair) looks terrible, same for the movement in combat etc.

Gameplay
I usually LIKE stealth games, but this one, I didn't. I am not sure whether it's just a higher difficulty or badly done game mechanics. Trying to sneak up on an enemy to take him out often ends up in frustration, as he notices you. However, it feels like the mechanics are just clunky, it's not some overly high AI or bad playing... I have played several stealth games and usually do ok, but here, I tried to sneak up on an enemy, and sometimes, the silent takedown works, sometimes he suddenly alerts everyone around him.

AI
Terrible. On one hand, the second the alarm is raised, they know EXACTLY where you are and shoot at you, which I find HIGHLY unrealistic. I wouldn't mind if they had a general idea quickly and then search for you there, but the second an alarm is raised, it's like they have a hive intelligence and know where you are.
At the same time, I have seen some moonwalking, and you can just run towards them and take them down with melee

Combat
Terrible as well. If there are two obstacles, and you aim between them and aim PERFECTLY at the head of an enemy, you won't hit him. Let me get this straight - two obstacles, you aim between them (yes, there is room between them), and you won't hit him.
Even when in range, and the dot in your targeting circle is aligned with someones head, you often miss. Having to shoot someone in the head (they wear a mask, or sometimes just a bandana, apparently these items generate a bullet proof forcefield) isn't exactly that realistic either.

Minigames
There is lockpicking, disabling alarms and hacking. The first two are... ok. The first one is even fun sometimes (balancing the cylinders of the lock, then releasing your lockpick, with a time limit). The second one is ok. The third one is horrible. Not going into details, the other commenters have commented on how terrible that one is many times.

Characters
I didn't like the whole intro, the conversations, the character design. Apart from simply looking odd, I just didn't care for any character, and I didn't like the main character either, who looks like a mix between Shepherd from Mass Effect and some kind of cyborg.

Overall
So much potential. I'd have liked to explore the game more and find all the things that those who liked the game praised... the decision-making, the email conversations or whatever.
However, the intro went on for too long and didn't grab me at all, and the two missions I tried were simply not fun at all. It's not the very outdated (even for a 2010-game!) look, it's the clunky mechanics, bad AI, horrible sneaking mechanics (MGS V and even Sniper Elite 2 and 3 do this SO much better), bad animation, horrible combat/aiming and the minigames.

It's sad, because I was looking forward to trying this, I was very much willing to give it a chance, but I have no interest at all to continue after these two missions.
If you can get it on sale (I got it for like 3 or 4 bucks), maybe try it out, but unfortunately, I simply can't recommend it.

reviewText:
TLDR VERDICTOverall, I can’t really objectively recommend Alpha Protocol. It has a wonderful premise that works well in some places, but ultimately fails in a lot more. If you value story over gameplay and you’re in the mood for a good espionage story, then buy this game on sale and breeze through it on easy to avoid frustration. If you’re looking for a good overall stealth action experience, then you won’t really find one here. Here’s hoping Obsidian actually get the time and resources to try a game like this again with a lot more polish.

FULL REVIEW BELOW
“The only thing I can say for sure, Mike, this business will change you.” – Yancy Westridge

Mike Thorton is the newest recruit in for the top secret US government agency known as Alpha Protocol. His first assignment for the agency seems to be stopping a standard terrorist plot, which rapidly evolves into a globe-trotting conspiracy hunt.

This review is written from the perspective of a fan of stealth action games with an emphasis on multiple approaches. Also a fan of story driven RPGs.

GAMEPLAY AND DESIGNAlpha Protocol’s gameplay is not its best asset. The level designs are largely linear stealth action arenas that don’t offer a lot of room for natural exploration or experimentation. There sometimes are hidden rooms that offer loot or alternate routes, but they are few and far between. If you want accurate expectations, you need to dismiss the notion that Alpha Protocol can be played as a pure stealth game from start to finish. Despite the tagline “the espionage RPG”, there are missions clearly designed for stealth, combat and mixtures of the two. If you try to employ combat in a stealth section or stealth in a combat section you’re just going to get frustrated. The problem is that game doesn’t exactly make clear what’s coming, requiring the player to employ some forethought, versatility and adaptability. It sounds neat, but can get frustrating when you show up in full combat gear to a stealth mission or vice versa.

The combat and stealth mechanics are a mixed bag. It employs are variation on Deus Ex 1s gunplay, where you basically can’t aim at all until you put enough points into that guns skill. It’s sounds cool, but at the end you basically end up with these horribly over-powered cooldown based weapon abilities that can 1 or 2 shot bosses. The bosses are another negative point for the game. A few of them can be beaten with stealth, but most of them are bullet sponges that you have to take on directly. It reminds me of a similar frustration I had in Deus Ex: Human Revolution, where you would manage your inventory and skills for one playstyle, only to run into a boss that demands another. These inconsistent difficulty spikes are irritatingly prevalent throughout the whole game. Sometimes it seems like the AI has a field of view of 45 degrees in front of them and sometimes it’s like they have eyes on the backs of their heads. The obstacles that enemies can and can’t see through are also inconsistent. The combat AI is smart enough, taking cover and using grenades etc. The stealth AI is less so. They like to stick to predictable paths, can’t hear anything and bodies can’t be moved so they hardly ever spot them.

The character progression system is very Mass Effect 1-esque. There are skills that are weapon based and the rest help with other aspects of the game (stealth, hacking etc.). Points can award you with passive abilities and active abilities. The progression starts pretty steady, but as mentioned before, by the end if you specialised correctly you can run around invisible, one shotting everything. Not an exaggeration.

STORY AND NARRATIVEThe story and the way Alpha Protocol handles conversations is easily my favourite aspect of it. The conversation options are timed and almost always boil down to 3 responses. You can be a James Bond style suave guy; an Agent 47 professional guy; or just an all-out aggressive ♥♥♥♥♥♥-nozzle. Different characters will respond to different tones accordingly and this can affect how much they like or dislike you. You can use this to your advantage, making your handlers and potential assets like you for information and perks and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ off enemies to make them easier to beat. The game provides loads of dossiers with two distinct categories: individuals and organisations. Organisation dossiers are pretty straight forward, and are mostly used to give you a rundown of opposition tactics. Individual dossiers are more interesting, as you can exploit the information in them to find out what sort of responses people would like/dislike and times use secret facts in a conversation which have varying special results. For example, you can actually use dossier information in conversations to make two bosses turn on each other later making the fight a breeze. Of course, these options only appear if you actually read the dossiers, which feels pretty damn cool for a spy game.

The story itself is structured pretty similarly to your standard Deus Ex game. You have a straightforward prologue that introduces you to the world and then spans into a globetrotting conspiracy hunt. The game does a good job of conveying the feeling of unravelling the plot as you progress, discovering (or even predicting) plot twists as they are thrown at you. There are plenty of choices in the game that are all very morally ambiguous and open-ended in true Obsidian fashion. The factions you side with and ♥♥♥♥ off can have fairly significant effects on the rest of the game both during gameplay and in the story. You can try to be good or evil, but most choices boil down to picking between two awful things, which is great.

The actual voice acting in this game is surprisingly not half bad for the most part. This is surprising, considering the rough patches the rest of the game has. Aside from a few specific moments, the voice acting holds up for the most part.

GRAPHICS AND PERFORMANCEAlpha Protocol is a rough looking game, even for its time (2010). The character models and animations are pretty terrible, texture work is very mediocre, and relying on lighting and shadow effects to stay hidden will almost always backfire. The animations in general are pretty laughable. This especially stands out when patrolling enemies freak out for a second when changing direction. The martial arts moves look pretty janky as well. A very average looking game, not dated enough to deter me, but not exactly anything to marvel at either.

Performance-wise, Alpha Protocol is an Obsidian game. What this usually means, is there are a lot of bugs, cut content and a few performance hitches. Alpha Protocol is not a stranger to any of these issues. As mentioned before, the AI is horribly inconsistent, a lot of missions like to bug out when reloading checkpoints (which are designed terribly, no manual saves), and you get punished for breaking stealth or rules of engagement when you know you didn’t. The bugs and technical problems combined with the poor gameplay mechanics make a very frustrating pile of game to get through the gems for the story content, which is a damn shame because those gems can be brilliant at times.

reviewText: This game is clearly made by people who don't care. The mini-games to interact with electronic devices are all tedious and frustrating, the computer hacking one will make you go crazy. reviewText:
Don't bother with this. I'd heard it was pretty poor, but since it was cheap I decided to give it a go due to it's interesting spy espionage theme.

Basically everything is just badly executed. Stealth is too easy due to the braindead AI who will sit and stare at you for about 10 seconds before walking off. Combat is just boring because of it's generic structure and fairly odd aiming system. You can basically get around most of the areas with the standard grunt enemy through bugs and glitches - I know I did. Then you go up against a boss. These are pretty unfair and the only way you'll win is by hiding behind cover, slowly picking off each of the boss's goons and then shooting the boss in the face for about 20 minutes until their stupidly large health bar is empty.

The only thing this game really has going for it is it's storytelling, with all that choices and branching stuff, ya know what I mean? It was alright I guess, but since all the characters are cardboard cutouts of generic spy movie stereotypes I found it hard to be invested in the story at all.

So yeah, don't bother with this game, unless you're willing to devote some time into it. Personally, I couldn't be bothered to play more than 4 hours because it just had too many floors for my taste. However, I can appreciate why people do defend this game.
voteText: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I had such high hopes for this game, I don't know why. Uninspired and cumbersome design, annoying glitches and characters that range from the dull to downright offensive make this game a chore to play. The fact that players need to keep their reticules perfectly still for several agonizing seconds to gain accuracy while the opponents bob and weave through cover is frustrating. The decision to force players to specialize and force them into cookie cutter situations anyway is pants-crappingly ♥♥♥♥♥♥, because it forces the player to completely respec their stealth specialist into an assault trooper every time a boss rolls around. Sticky cover ruins the gunfights. The writing suggests a mind-numbingly simple view of world politics where the question whether the ends justify the means doesn't even come up. The illusion of choice basically comes down to what kind of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ you want to be. The plot doesn't connect to any sense of impact or urgency, because characters run a gamut of paperthin stereotypes. Women in particular seem to have little depth, with boosting the male player's ego as their main function. A comparison with old school Bond movies is apt, except that Alpha Protocol seems to take itself more seriously. maybe it's that AP takes place in a realistic setting, but I can't shake the thought that protagonist Mike Thornton is a sociopath no matter how you play him. I tried to play him as a decent human being but the game just doesn't allow that. Some of the dialogue options are openly misogynistic, despite being labeled 'joking'. If that is how the writers think, then that's ♥♥♥♥ed up. Even at a discount, this was a mistake to buy.

reviewText:
Overall score: 5/10

The game isn´t that bad, in fact it seems really awesome at the beginning. It feels like a Mass Effect 2 with better controls, more content and more interaction possibilities. At the beginning, that is.

As soon as you get into your HQ and start doing missions, the game becomes extremely boring because its very repetitive.

Here a summary of the first two hours:
Arrive in HQ, look around and explore the rooms in your HQ, buy stuff for your inventory/gear, go into a mission in mid east, kill bad guys, return to HQ, buy stuff for your inventory, go into mission in mid east, kill bad guys, return to HQ, ...

and so on.
After two hours I was fed up with the game, and uninstalled it.

The teammates seemed rather dull and boring, I didnt feel any obligation or interest to listen to the stuff they wanted to tell me, so I just tl;dr´d 75% of the conversations as soon as I noticed that it was going to be a boring dialogue.

The many ways to kill or not kill and move or sneak around the maps are there, but not necessary nor effective. There hasnt been a single scenario where sneaking around the whole map and silently killing enemies would have been as efficient as just going full Rambo-mode on them.

The weapons feel weird. Extremely inaccurate even when you crouch and aim down the sights. So I mostly took them out with stationed MGs.

Overall... meh. Its kind of okay, but it gets boring very quickly.

reviewText:
I really wanted to like this game, as a Modern Espionage action RPG it fills a niche that no other game before or since has tried to. But the controls are so broken and the combat mechanics so terrible that I simply could not.

The story is compelling, the game's concept is interesting, but the execution falls flat.

The hacking mini-game, the mastering of which is critical to the game, is nearly impossible to do with the keyboard and mouse combo; fortunately this game does support gamepads as clearly this game was designed for consoles and the PC port was a sloppy after thought.

Every now and then I look for mods for this game, something to un-♥♥♥♥ the gameplay, but I have yet to find anything that fixes the gameplay. Which is a damn shame: the first mission really drew me in to this game's story, but Alpha Protocol's broken game mechanics pushed me right back out.

reviewText:
I cannot believe I was stupid enough to impulse-buy this ♥♥♥♥ing game for fifteen ♥♥♥♥ing dollars. It is horribly, mind blowingly generic. The generic, boring blandness of this game is just outstanding. It washed over me like the tidal wave crashing down on Patrick Swayze at the end of Point Break. It is like a copy of Splinter Cell Conviction, if of course you took every single last tiny detail about that game that made it so great including sound, gameplay, and graphics, and flushed it all down the toilet, then you have this game. I was shaking my head at how bad it is the entire time I was playing it. A worthless ♥♥♥♥ing waste of anyones time. And I mean anyone. I hope anyone involved with making this game ♥♥♥♥ing dies.

The stealth part of the game, if you can even call it that, just sucks nuts. The worst thing about this game is how horribly, mind bogglingly inaccurate all weapons are. I seriously wonder what the ♥♥♥♥ they were thinking when they did this. Pistols = luck. Assault rifles = horrible. And shotguns = I can be right in front of a guy not more than 4ft away, aiming directly into his upper torso with the shotgun, and where any other shotgun, game or real life, would blow a hole right through him, 95% of the pellets miss him. It's as bad if not worse than the shotgun in Doom 3. You might be able to increase accuracy with obtained mods and skills as the game progresses but it's too bad this game just generally sucks so bad and is such a overall ♥♥♥♥♥♥ poorly made game that you won't want to. One of the worst games I've ever played. The level design is horrible: incredibly linear and you go from one box shaped room or area to the next box shaped one while killing incompetant enemies with the most innaccurate weapons ever put in a game. The graphics are really bad and the levels all use the same God awful boring colors.

You want a game like this that is actually fun? Play Binary Domain instead. Or any Splinter Cell game for that matter. You know what, thumb wrestling is more fun than this garbage.

Yet another game that completely sucks in general terms but I get all downvotes because people think, for whatever ♥♥♥♥ed up reasoning, that it has any redeeming qualities, in which it actually has exactly zero. If you like this game I feel bad for how easily impressible you are and your taste in games must be incredibly bad. 3/10
