reviewText:
TL;DR - Clunky interface, don't recommend.

It took me 75 minutes to get through the tutorial and one of the training missions.  I spent about 20 of those 75 minutes trying to figure out the awful hacking mini-game.  How someone could design a mess like that and then think it's a good idea is baffling.

I should have quit after the hacking tutorial, but I had heard this was a good RPG, so I pressed on.  The next thing I know I'm doing the grenade training mission and getting beat up by all the guards I had knocked out during the tutorial.  I tried fighting back but I couldn't figure out the magic keys on my keyboard to throw a punch.  Spacebar?  F key? RMB?  Don't know.

There is also apparently some kind of reputation system, however the dialog options are only on the screen for about 2 seconds giving you no time to read and process what option to choose.  Again, how can a designer think this is a good idea.

I finally gave up and went back to XCOM 2.

reviewText: I can't recommend this sadly. I want to. and I want to keep playing, but not for all,  but for many ( I have been reading forums) this game is  unplayable. I have over 100 games in my steam account, newer and older, I run those games at higher settings than this game. every time  I'm playing every instance, I rotate the camera, it turns very painfully slow, when facing a close blank wall, but as soon as it turns to the more open environment, the camera speeds by so fast when moving the mouse. I can't even aim the gun. I tried to lower all the settings, even manually with the Nvidia settings, nothing works. I for one can't play this game as bad as I want to. I progressed through the first level, and I can't even get this to remotely be playable now at all, especially in this map of the desert.  i turn and face the wall again, and the camera moves normally, then the same movement of the mouse that BARELY turns the camera, all of a sudden rockets so fast, that I try to aim at an enemy, and I keep zooming passed him from one side to the other, while barely moving the mouse at all. for me (and many others I read also) this makes this game absolutely unplayable. how said.  I truly wantyed to play this one, especially with the stealth. I love stealth type games. so if you buy this game anyways, and get the above described problem, don't say I didn't warn you. However there are others., who claim this game works fine for them, so.. it's a risk you will have to weigh yourselves. for me this game is broken as a result of unplayable camera control.. terribly bad

reviewText: Buggy, linear, and generally not as open as it advertises. The game says you can solve problems with any number of different approaches, from Stealth, to gadet use, to open combat. However, in reality the game is obviously meant to be a stealth game. If you try playing it like a shooter (running around, using cover, shotgunning it up) you can beat the game, but you will fail a ton of secondary objectives. Almost every mission the game is telling you to sneak around and not be seen, so why are shotguns, uzis, and assault rifles available to the player when the game really, really wants you to use a silenced pistol (or fists I suppose)?\n\nAll-in-all a mediocre game with very little room for customization and character building. I never felt like I was the Agent, I just felt like I was watching his story.

reviewText:
Recommended but ,read some details below.
Overall, this game looks like if it was made ten years ago.
Somewhat an RPG, 3rd person action and stealth game, which sounds really interesting, right?.
In the ballpark of splinter cell.

In the positive side, story is interesting and deep. Missions are variated. Each dialogue has several alternative attitudes to answer, which directly impacts in relationships with main characters. Black Market to personalize your equipment and to gather some info, is also a good thing.
It's somewhat similar to early Splinter Cell games, including door lock cracking, digital pannels, PC and survilance cameras control.
So, the overall design of the game is interesting enough.

In the negative side, controls are a tad sloppy and, particularly, camera (or head) rotation. Enemies IA lacks the I, they suddenly attack you (even if you are stealthing and they are far away) or, they ignore you while killing one enemy beside other. That's weird and, probably the two things that rest points to a game that, otherwise, would be a great one.

Difficulty is easy, in normal mode. It's really difficult to dead during fights. Stealth has not so much importance. You end killing everybody, at the end.
But the few bosss are really hard to bate.
Game has hours of playing so, you will be entertained for a while.
The balance in relationships between your character and other main characters is difficult to achieve and, depends on which attitude you are selecting for each conversation chunk. This helps to increase that sensation that you  don't know who to trust and, who are the good boys.

reviewText:
Shooting is functional (frankly I’m no expert on the matter, as far as I’m concerned “You point at people and they die” is the pinnacle of the shooter experience), but the RPG elements are really well thought, you can feel your character becoming progressively more powerful over time, maybe slightly OP.

The plot is… Somewhat of a mess. There’s a lot of different secret agencies making their moves in the background, and it might be difficult to wrap your head around at first, especially since certain crucial info is only unlocked through different decisions along the way.
BUT, the plot also adapts really well to the decisions you make along the way, and your play style. It feels like your actions carry weight, and the plot develops accordingly. While the final level plays the same, your character might have an entirely different motivation, and the final boss might be entirely different people. It adds to the replayabitliy, and I think the game truly shines only on the second play through.

Overall, I recommend Alpha Protocol. It offers a nice blend of stealth and shooter, and the RPG elements complement either playstyle.

reviewText:
I really can't say too much since I barely got started in the game, but if you're looking for a good stealth game, then you won't find one here.
Two of the golden rules of stealth game design is to not have enemies spot you if they only see a part of you for less than a second, and that the alarm doesn't immediately go off if you have been spotted so that you have chance to silence the guard. This game botches both of those things, along with having annoying characters and stiff controls.

After I got to the game hub I started with doing the espionage training, which went alright except for me getting detected by one of the guards. I tried again and happened to do the exact same mistake, and I ended up with the same score of 88 points. The next time I wanted to rush it more, but got detected by the first camera, so I decided to leg it to the end to quickly restart. I fisticuffed both guards after each of them had raised the alarm, and I got spotted by each and every camera, but even so I ended up with a score of 133. [b1]F-cking. What.[/b1] So apparently [b1]stealth[/b1] doesn't matter in the [b1]stealth[/b1] evaluation mission.

I then tried the extra credit course for espionage which involved me backtracking to the start of the game. It went swimmingly up until I got back to the last room of the assignment, where the guards had been redeployed 30 seconds after me emptying the room. I wasn't expecting the game to be a ♥♥♥♥ like that and my carelessness had the guard spot my right thigh for half a second before opening fire and immediately sounding the alarm. I tried to flank him through a sideroom, but he was already shooting at me the moment I opened the door, and I was gunned to death.

So the stealth's absolute ♥♥♥♥.
The camera is stiff.
I chose to play with a gamepad, but you get two speeds: brisk walking pace and a slight run/fast jog which also feels stiff.
The character animations are really stiff and unnatural, I am almost assuming that they didn't use mocap for it.
The gunplay also feels extremely stiffEvery aspect of the gameplay controls like ♥♥♥♥, and I don't even mind the Mako in Mass Effect.

I really like Obsidian though; Fallout New Vegas is one of my favourite games ever, and I can overlook the technical flaws and re-use of assets just because the world, story and dialogue is so good, but this game loses points for that as well with the main character probably being the most annoying ♥♥♥♥♥♥ in videogaming history. Every line of dialogue is just so annoying that I started choosing the professional" dialogue option as often as I could
date: but even with that he goes off with annoying quips. He is like a mix between the suave and charming James Bond but with the delivery and attitude of an entitled arrogant tosser who just begs to get his teeth kicked in just with his smug grin.\nSpeaking of the dialogue
recommended: the dialogue wheel is even worse than the one in Fallout 4

reviewText:
An overwrought, undercooked spy action RPG choose your own adventure. Written by people who have absolutely no idea how real human beings talk but like to dazzle you with constant back and forth half answers so you get confused and think you're watching clever people joust verbally.

Still worth trucking through the lack of polish and the dour writing because, hey, when you're trying so, SO hard to be clever, you actually end up sometimes being clever despite yourself. The bosses are more interesting than you'd expect in a Syphon Filter-esque TPS baked with RPG. The array of characters each with different personalities and motivations and schemes to keep straight is dizzying and you are constantly making friends, enemies, and choices. The plot itself may be limp and boring but the way you navigate is far more interesting than anything that actually happens.

I could count the memorable scenes in this game on one hand, and the memorable lines of dialogue with the remaining fingers, but the ones that stick out are definitely interesting.

reviewText:
Alpha Protocol is a game that I really wanted to like. I tried to look past the flaws that this game had, but I honestly couldn't. The best thing I can say about Alpha Protocol is that it at least tried to be something different, but even if you try to do something different, it doesn't mean that it will always be good.

Alpha Protocol has a unique concept, an espionage RPG. I was surprised to see that this sort of idea, hadn't been done that often in gaming and that is one thing that I respect this game for doing. The main problem with this however is that in my opinion, Alpha Protocol doesn't really use any of the unique ideas it brings to the table that well and the basic stuff that are required to make a good game (like gameplay, playability and graphics) aren't really focused on as they put most of their thought, time and care into trying to implement these ideas to try and live up to it's name an espionage RPG."

One of the biggest problems Alpha Protocol has is in it's gameplay. Nearly everything in the gameplay falls flat. While the training section at the beginning of the game
date: does show off some great ideas for an espionage RPG like sneaking mechanics
hoursPlayed: I didn't feel like I was having any fun playing this or doing any of these ideas for gameplay because in the end
voteText: that's what I was thinking they were
helpfulPercent: just some ideas. I felt like these ideas were only half executed. The ideas are there
votesHelpful: but they just stopped after that. Sneaking is basically useless because the AI is really bad. Gun combat feels restricted an the sensitivity never feels right no matter what you set it to. Melee combat
votesTotal: while it's better than gun combat
votesFunny: feels slippery for the majority of the time
commentsCount: but at least it was more controllable than the gun Gadgets are basically useless in combat because you can't really tell where they'll land. There's no targeting ridicule for them so you just need to predict where they'll land.\n\nGraphics are for the most part good however there are several flaws with them. There is quite a lot of slow loading textures from time to time and the longer I played
column16: the more frequently these occurred. There is also a bit of pop in going on quite a bit. Apart from that there isn't much to say about the graphics. They're decent but they could have gotten more polish before release like the rest of the game.\n\nThe sound seemed to repeatedly cutting out randomly for some reason throughout my play time as well. However
column17: this didn't affect my overall feeling towards the game in any way and I easily ignored it as it wasn't too big of a deal.\n\nIn this review
column18: it might come off like I hate Alpha Protocol and even though that's true
column19: there's still some good ideas that are put into Alpha Protocol
column20: which might have been good if they developed these ideas further. The stuff that is common to see and expect in an RPG is present in Alpha Protocol but these things we have seen done a bunch of times are exactly that. Alpha Protocol does nothing to change the styles that are common in RPGs except for the dialogue options
column21: which is one of the best I've seen.\n\nOverall
column22: Alpha Protocol is buggy and generic. It barely does anything to stand out from the crowd and when it tries to do this
column24: it still uses some ideas which I hope to see in RPGs in a future and if the developers of this game were to make a sequel
column25: maybe tweaking the game a bit
column26:
I would definitely buy the sequel to see if these ideas are developed more.

Pros
+ Some good ideas
+ Great concept
+ Good mechanics
+ OK graphics

Cons
- Underdeveloped ideas
- Terrible AI
- Restricted/slippery combat
- Slow loading textures

Final verdict: 3/10

reviewText: I bought this game expecting a tense spy drama like Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy or The Americans. After spending 10 minutes preparing the perfect disguise for my initial mission, the arms dealer's henchmen immediately read me as American and opened fire. So much for spying. Well, perhaps i could at least sneak? Nope. Aside from the janky controls and flaky stealth mechanics, the game repeatedly forces you into frontal assaults anyway. The most appalling part, for me, is when it proudly sums up all your kills at the end of the mission, and awards you perks for them, which really drives home just how messed up the story is. Running around killing (or even just" disabling) hundreds of foreign nationals without any rules of engagement made me feel a lot more like a terrorist than an operative.\n\nAnd it's a shame because there is some good dialog in there. The story is in the vein of Nikita
recommended: and it is fun to choose alliances and watch the drama unfold. Just fun enough for me to complete the game. But the boss battles
hoursPlayed: the waves of enemies
voteText: the woefully linear levels... At some points in the game you have to make life or death decisions
helpfulPercent: but i just didn't care because the majority of the game is built around you killing people with no consequence at all. If there had been more dialog
votesTotal: an open world to explore
votesFunny: any opportunity to downshift and become invested in the places i visited
commentsCount: then the poor decisions i made may have had some emotional resonance. Instead i was sent straight on to the next mission with more faceless bad guys and superhuman bosses to kill. Hard to recommend unless you are really craving a spy fix and are willing to put up with a lot of mindless shooting."

reviewText:
If you picked the Bug (right, bugs) the Airfield mission as your first mission out of three, you WILL think this game sucks:

-Enemies sometimes can see you even though you are behind a cover. This happened to me twice in that mission. What's the point of encouraging stealth approach while the gunner can see you through the cover and pull the alarm?

-The game has checkpoints while it also allows you to save/load at anytime during a mission. However when I reloaded the checkpoint in the Bug the Airfield mission, all the enemies in the area disappeared. This bug is helpful for me to explore the area, but it completely ruins the fun of the game. However those issues are not that severe in the later missions.

Also, sometimes you can't climb ladders or get behind the cover unless you adjust your camera position or simply try again". Such problems are quite devastating if you want to go for a stealth approach.

Besides the technical issues
date: Alpha Protocol is full of dialogues and text if you like narrative elements in a game.\n\nI wouldn't recommend this game to a friend
recommended: because the bugs are ruining the gameplay experience. If you are curious about the game
hoursPlayed: feel free to pick it up."

reviewText: I have never found a game I was sick of within such a short time. And the sad thing is, it looked great. Realistic stealth takedowns and being able to choose your response type, building or ruining relationships and having positive or negative consequences for either and customization. This game looked like gold. And people said it was gold minus a few bugs.\n\nBut that's just it. I went into mission one ready for a great experience and I'm already being seen from literally across the map and alarms are raised without any trace of me doing anything. I wouldn't mind messing up and being seen, but humans don't have x-ray vision. Another problem is your character has to stand up every single time he switches cover, so it makes the mechanic completely useless and what with AI being able to be God already without being near them, you will be seen. This game was released in 2010. It's been 5 years and still these bugs are there? Alright Sega. There's my hard earned 3 dollars for you. I didn't expect to see current or next gen games from Sega this broken. That really disappoints. If the bugs were fixed it'd be perfect. But Sega clearly didn't care about this title. So please save your money on this one.

reviewText:
I never quit a game. Even if I don't like it a whole lot, I push through and finish.

Alpha Protocol made me give up. On the last dang mission. After level after level of poor design, terrible aiming, weird characters, and glitches galore, I quit. The random difficulty spikes, the average story, and the absolute worst set of hacking mini-games ever created all made this game mostly an unpleasant experience.

There were some fun characters (and I got my dude to bang the 3 hot chicks in the story so thats fun) and an occasional fun level or two, but for the most part, this game was absolute bullcrap.

There is a boss level in the final level that I finally gave up on because I experienced 3 seperate glitches that made me restart each time. So yea, I am not reccomending this game for you.

reviewText:
Before Alpha Protocol, I didn't know Obsidian Entertainment existed. I didn't know they developed Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic II, I didn't know they made Fallout: New Vegas, and I didn't know they created the Neverwinter Nights series. Heck, it wasn't until my second playthrough of Alpha Protcol almost half a year later that I discovered how much I really, really like this game.

Obsidian Entertainment is best known for being the developer other developers hand their franchises to when they hit a creative rut. Bioware handed them Knights of the Old Republic, and Bethesda handed them Fallout. In both cases, Obsidian took those franchises and surpassed the original games.

Alpha Protocol, while technically released after Fallout: New Vegas, could be seen as Obsidian's first original IP since Neverwinter Nights, and boy is it an ambitious one. Alpha Protocol is an action-y/stealth-y/gadget-y/spy-y with aspirations to being everything that Mass Effect promised to be. It plays like a movie, emphasizes player choice, and offers a diverse number of playstyles.

It comes within micrometers of being one of my favorite games. It's so close to being perfect that I can almost smell it. With some tweaking, the stealth could be great, the shooting fun, and the storyline fascinating. Unfortunately, small things muck up the gameplay. Stealth is hampered by the lack of attention the boss battles pay to it, alongside inconsistent NPC fields of view. The story is... well, while it's very nicely presented, it tends to be an incomprehensible mess.

I didn't have much of an idea what was going on until my second playthrough.

But despite the flaws, Alpha Protocol is very, very good. For all its flaws, it's an ambitious game, and it earns an easy recommendation from me.

reviewText:
I don't recommend playing this clunky mess of a game without quite a bit of tolerance.

Obsidian used to make remarkably well written fully fleshed out dialogue options with a lot of branching options and you had all the time in the world to consider and enjoy them. In AP you only get one word, that is only a type or mood of response, that represents an entire tree of dialogue that just play out by itself and you only get three seconds to decide and on picking that choice the design is quite unresponsive. You can highlight a response, thinking it's all good, but you need to click on the text inside to enable it.. Clunky. How can you assume that there is any roleplay in conversation if you have no idea, what you are saying? It's just a gamble then and gamling is not roleplaying. The most annoying part in this regards is that game autosaves AFTER each conversation.

The game has a bit of replay value, because of the non-sensical dialogue system of course and in different ways of playing it with focus on different guns (i.e. different combat strategies) and skills, but unfortunately the more you play it the more it falls apart and reveals the inconsistencies. You can master the game and break it.

The game itself doesn't play on the same conditions as the player. There are lots of scripts and triggers to ruin your gameplay like enemies that alert everybody to your presense in a split second before they pass out. I can't prime a grenade and when I throw it there is always a delay before it explodes that pretty much makes them useless to me in combat, but when an enemy lop a grenade my way it explodes almost instantly. It's also quite rare that I actually manage to complete a throw, because it will bounce off or against walls that I didn't notice.

For a game with the title Espionage RPG there is a remarkable lack of espionage and barely any RPG. You can't spy on anyone, you can't select your own targets, nothing happens unless the game serves it all on a platter for you. You can only request information if it's for sale, not because you want to check up on somebody. There should have been an option to request data on anyone you want to check out, but there isn't. There is no spying. Calling this game RPG at all, that's really far fetched. It's much more of Action Adventure with skill-progression than anything else.

I had a lot of mouse issues with this game, because in menus it moved in one way, which was okay and in combat another way which was also okay, but a third way in Sniper mode, which was extremely sensitive and a fourth way in minigames, where the cursor moved in completely erratic patterns, which made it impossible for me to use the Sniper at all and made me fail pretty much every minigame.. I had to fiddle around with ini files to lessen the pain, but I couldn't remove it.

The main character is in a bit of the same vein as Shepard in Mass Effect i.e. boring and forgettable, but there are a few colourful characters that adds all the fun and sexiness of the game.. Take those (two) away and the game would have a been a total disaster.

It happened on numerous occassions that enemies respawned in my face and just stared blankly at me..

It was a bit entertaining, but it's very much a - Been there, done that - kind of game.

reviewText: This was...okay. I'm not sure what happened with this game. The recommended game requirements suggested my computer had what it took to run this with no problem but I jump in and it's choppy, the aiming took hours to adapt to the way the crosshairs jumped around, it's buggy as all hell and at times the dialog could be downright corny as the worse B-movie you've ever seen; plus it is truly the type of game you need a strategy guide open at all times if you want things to go the way you want them to. But it was different, the story was at least half-way interesting and the narrative can change depending on your choices throughout the game. There's a lot to complain about but if there was a part two in the future I would consider it depending on what the reviews say about what has been improved. In summary, buyer beware.

reviewText:
In the hour that I've played this game, I wasn't appealed by it. Alpha Protocol boxes with the greater spy-espionage games by entering itself into the genre with its elements. The potential is there, but I couldn't recommend it because of the fact the gameplay itself is unrefined. The graphics are beautiful, as well as the controls. The story line is your typical run-of-the-mill type which everybody can basically predict. There will be a lot of places where you get stuck if you don't memorize basically the whole layout of the game, which will easily aggrivate even the most seasoned of espionage veterans to a hightened extent. Your movements and timing have to be very intricate, as if you're playing a deep game of chess. Having to reload your checkpoints and redo whole sections of the game over and over again because you missed one tiny detail gets menotonous and dull very quickly.

As I previously stated, the game has serious potential, but in my eyes, it's unfinished at best.

If you're a hardcore espionage veteran, then I could recommend this game to you. If not, then I'd stay on the tracks of Syphon Filter or games such as. I wouldn't recommend this game for casual players at all.

reviewText:
7/10
A quite good mixture of Splinter Cell (stealth), Hitman (weapon upgrading), Mass Effect (situation/story influencing dialogue options) and Metal Gear (clothing and armor either make you silent like a cat or loud like an army troop).
And you even have skills you can level up.

This game can be frustrating if you're focussing on stealth, though. It only has checkpoints and you will have to reload them often if you want to avoid getting spotted by cameras or guards.

reviewText:
If the game isn't worth 50% of its price, I won't recommend it at all, and that is the case here.

Good:
+ Timed dialogue keeps you involved in the story
+ The missions are decently varied
+ You can go either full lethal or full nonlethal
+ Decent variation in character builds
+ Decent variation in roleplaying options in dialogue

Bad:
- Levels balanced horribly: some builds completely unviable for certain levels
- Checkpoint system with no manual save for no other reason than Halo and consolitis
- Checkpoints are way too far apart: hope you can do everything right the first time
- Dialogue horribly cheesy
- Story utterly banal, Clancyesque, perhaps on the level of Army of Two, about PMCs and the military-industrial complex
- Numerous bugs: often after reloading a checkpoint because you died from poor level design, enemies and the opportunity to collect their XP will vanish
- Not open world and hardly even a hub; the safehouses just exist as extended inventory screens
- Attempts Deus Ex-style gameplay variation but without the numerous routes and proper scaling you would expect
- Graphics about as awful as you could expect of Unreal Engine 3
- Reputation gain/loss dialogue options sometimes are unpredictable, even after reading dossiers
- Weapons absurdly inaccurate for a supposedly trained agent (hearkens back to DX where you basically have to master firearms skills to be using them)
- Quite short: even if it were padded out with open world retreading it would still be less than 15 hours long
- Ridiculously strong, GTA" bosses with giant health pools that you have to pour hundreds of rounds into
date: including an emo teen girl\n- Keyboard + mouse controls completely terrible: hacking next to impossible in this setup (consider gamepad required)\n- For a game about espionage
recommended: stealth is totally naff with enemies that can see in the dark across unlit fields
hoursPlayed: few avoidance routes and mechanics that are between Zelda 64 and Metal Gear Solid chronologically (1998 or so; of course less detailed than Thief 1)\n- For a game where stealth is terrible

reviewText:
In almost every aspect attributable to a videogame, Alpha Protocol fails to impress. The graphics are ugly, the artstyle is generic, the gunplay is tripe and the AI borderline schizophrenic.
It is a testament, then, to Obisdian's writing staff that this game is merely mediocre.

The game has a solid RPG heritage and this shows, with the RPG elements arguably being the game's only true strength. There are some solid choice and consequences here and the leveling system is basic, but functional (operating on a hybrid of perks and number-based attribute upgrades). The story the game weaves between flashbacks is not in itself ground-breaking nor is it free from a number of tried and tested spy clichés, but the influence the game allows you to have on the story is commendable. There's no TW2-tier decision here, but characters will reflect on how you played a level and this will result in other characters reacting accordingly. For example, playing steathily throughout will mean characters that respect stealthy-operators are more likely to respect you and your methods, perhaps resulting in an allegiance several levels later. These are relatively minor touches, but they permeate the game's writing, with the game itself having a number of different endings depending on who you allied with and how friendly you were with them.

The gunplay is heavily influenced by the RPG mechanics of old, with the reticule taking some time to focus on weapons you are not trained for. However, even when your character is maxed out on a weapon's skill, the gunplay fails to feel anything better than floaty and ill-equipped. I ended up playing as a sneaky spy in an effort to avoid the gunplay.
Stealth in this game is hampered by the AI. It's laughably stupid in some cases and borderline psychic in others. The game gets around this in later levels by allowing your character to become invisible (with no in-game reasoning as to why) but this quickly becomes over-powered as your pour more points into stealth.

To be sure, I found Alpha Protocol a deeply unsatisfying experience, but I found myself constantly wanting to like it as I progressed, there's a distinct lack of good RPGs set in the spy mythos. This is a game that was clearly crafted with a small budget and unlike other budget games (such as DMC1) which inspire a certain cheap charm to them, you can't help but lament the lost potential with Alpha Protocol.

reviewText:
An exercise in frustration!!!  I REALLY wanted to love this game and bought it when it first came out, because I thought the story was intriguing and there were choices in dialog etc.  I love Deus Ex, so when I saw this game I thought yeah this is gonna be a great game with a different story line, different type of character and menu system.  I'm a completionist type player, and if you aren't a completionist then this review won't be any use to you.

Let me start with the hacking...  the tutorial at the beginning of the game is useless, and it took me several tries over the years to eventually get past it.  I'd try and then get annoyed then stop playing, then I picked up the game up again and give it another try, and so on.  Use google and read the endless amount of people who hate the hacking as much as I do.  One guy says look for the string that doesn't move, which does work! I can get the right string set, however I can't activate the left string EVER even when I find it because for some stupid reason the  key that the instructions on the bottom to set it doesn't work.  Each string uses a different key to set it the string for left and right.

Now after endless reading on what others have tried to make the hacking simpler, with the string hacks and some even say avoid hacking and move on.  Okay I could do that, skip hacking all together.  However if you are a completionist type player who's aim is to earn as much exp as possible to develop the character to the max this is going to be an irritating feeling of leaving things undone!

Also if you are a completionist aiming to get the most exp pts per mission/dialog etc the checkpoints are going to be an irritation as well.  For instance if you accidentally chose the wrong thing in dialog and lost a reputation point with someone too bad.  This happened to me during a dialog and my phone rang and well let's just say the game forces you to be chained to your chair and disregard what goes on in real life.  If this doesn't bother you, then no worries.. however I like the feeling of physical freedom.  When the dialog gets screwed up because I am addressing something in real life like answering the phone, it's like I'm being punished.  To me it's a design flaw in the game, and the devs didn't take any consideration to real life when the game is on.  True you could reload a checkpoint, yay you get to do the section all over again.. kinda like punishment. IMO there should not be a checkpoint save systems in this type of game, with dialog choices.

I play with a keyboard and mouse and I read on the forums that this game isn't too friendly with them.  Maybe that's my problem with the hacking, who knows?  I know the mouse and keyboard work fine with combat movement, and the combat is kinda ABC 123/no brainer.

I bought this game when it first came out over 3 years ago and then tried it again over 3 years later and I am still having issues.  I don't want to give it a thumbs down, but I feel I have to as not to confuse people because of the irritating features of the game.  The story  development I think I would like if I ever was able to play the game long enough to experience it.  However I've got a completionist type mentality, in any game I want to explore every area, I want to hone my choices to get the maximum expierience, if I don't then I feel like I'm missing parts of the game and have failed.  That's just me, I know there are plenty of people who are satisfied with not doing that.  Until I can change who I am, and lower my standards then I'll not be able to play the game to the end so I'm shelving it again.

If you don't think these things will bother you that I mentioned, then great.  I do suggest checking the forums on Steam and other sites to get a census of what experiences others had, before you buy.   I think the game would have had great potential as a series, irritating design mechanics aside. I guess there's a reason why there was never a follow up game to it, because maybe the hacking, and mach speed dialog chosing peaved too many people off.

Let me start with the hacking...  the tutorial at the beginning of the game is useless, and it took me several tries over the years to eventually get past it.  I'd try and then get annoyed then stop playing, then I picked up the game up again and give it another try, and so on.  Use google and read the endless amount of people who hate the hacking as much as I do.  One guy says look for the string that doesn't move, which does work! I can get the right string set, however I can't activate the left string EVER even when I find it because for some stupid reason the  key that the instructions on the bottom to set it doesn't work.  Each string uses a different key to set it the string for left and right.

Now after endless reading on what others have tried to make the hacking simpler, with the string hacks and some even say avoid hacking and move on.  Okay I could do that, skip hacking all together.  However if you are a completionist type player who's aim is to earn as much exp as possible to develop the character to the max this is going to be an irritating feeling of leaving things undone!

Also if you are a completionist aiming to get the most exp pts per mission/dialog etc the checkpoints are going to be an irritation as well.  For instance if you accidentally chose the wrong thing in dialog and lost a reputation point with someone too bad.  This happened to me during a dialog and my phone rang and well let's just say the game forces you to be chained to your chair and disregard what goes on in real life.  If this doesn't bother you, then no worries.. however I like the feeling of physical freedom.  When the dialog gets screwed up because I am addressing something in real life like answering the phone, it's like I'm being punished.  To me it's a design flaw in the game, and the devs didn't take any consideration to real life when the game is on.  True you could reload a checkpoint, yay you get to do the section all over again.. kinda like punishment. IMO there should not be a checkpoint save systems in this type of game, with dialog choices.

I play with a keyboard and mouse and I read on the forums that this game isn't too friendly with them.  Maybe that's my problem with the hacking, who knows?  I know the mouse and keyboard work fine with combat movement, and the combat is kinda ABC 123/no brainer.

I bought this game when it first came out over 3 years ago and then tried it again over 3 years later and I am still having issues.  I don't want to give it a thumbs down, but I feel I have to as not to confuse people because of the irritating features of the game.  The story  development I think I would like if I ever was able to play the game long enough to experience it.  However I've got a completionist type mentality, in any game I want to explore every area, I want to hone my choices to get the maximum expierience, if I don't then I feel like I'm missing parts of the game and have failed.  That's just me, I know there are plenty of people who are satisfied with not doing that.  Until I can change who I am, and lower my standards then I'll not be able to play the game to the end so I'm shelving it again.

If you don't think these things will bother you that I mentioned, then great.  I do suggest checking the forums on Steam and other sites to get a census of what experiences others had, before you buy.   I think the game would have had great potential as a series, irritating design mechanics aside. I guess there's a reason why there was never a follow up game to it, because maybe the hacking, and mach speed dialog chosing peaved too many people off.

reviewText:
Alpha Protocol fails to impress on any level.

Pros:  Sound, Story
Cons:  Graphics, Control, Gameplay, Bugs

From the voice acting to the ambient sounds, Alpha Protocol, even in name, sounds good.  The story follows a more realistic route than most other games in the genre, which can be refreshing.

However, Alpha Protocol's graphics and animations appear dull and wooden, trailing behind even its 2010 peers.  Control is poor with both the controller and keyboard/mouse, though this is partly because of the biggest flaw: gameplay.  The gameplay is absolutely atrocious in every aspect.  The minigames irritate at first but later become so frustrating that bypass gadgets are a godsend.  The gunplay is poor; our 'elite' agent takes seconds to hit a still, unaware target.  The choices are misrepresented: 'suave' can be cheeky or it can be arrogant jerk, whatever the developer decided at the time.

Overall, Alpha Protocol is a mediocre port of a mediocre game.

6/10

reviewText: I would recommend picking this up if it goes on sale again.  I bought it for 2 dollars on sale and I played almost straight through it.  It is a VERY customizable spy rpg and it is pretty fun.  I know I didn't sneak around at all because that's not really my style so I just upgraded my characters ♥♥♥-kicking capabilities until he was able to rambo entire rooms full of enemies with only his fists.  That route takes some definite precise combo timing but is very fun.  If you play you will probably want to use either shotguns or your fists as CQ and AR or SMG as medium to long range.  The pistols are not very useful, sadly.\n\nDetractors from the experience are minor mostly.  The one thing I hated the most is the fact that you cannot jump at all, presumably to make the game easier to code, since you can only jump or do action man things when a symbol marks the area as an action man thing place and the game will run through a scripted action sequence. 1 ft high debris = insurmountable mtn :/

reviewText: Terrible combat and infuriating hacking minigames can't bring down the best (only?) spy RPG out there. It takes what the Bioware RPGs tried to do with dialog/morality and builds it into a much more organic system. Instead of paragon/renegade you have 3 directions that boil down to one of the three JBs: Jason Bourne (professional), Jack Bauer (aggressive) and James Bond (suave). Choose pistols and martial arts as your main combat abilities and laugh as you headshot and karate chop your way through the extremely well written story.\n\nSo many little choices and easter eggs that make each playthrough different. Also, just about everything Stephen Heck (one of your allies...mostly) does is pure gold.
